During Christmas, New Year, and Easter weeks they were summoned almost daily, sometimes twice a day. During processions, they followed the emperor and attended to the empress by supporting her dress train at turnings and spreading it out again. Each grand duchess was also followed by her page de chambre.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how did the narrator's view of Alexander II change over time?
response: Initially, the narrator looked upon Alexander II as a sort of hero who attached no importance to Court ceremonies and worked hard from six in the morning, struggling against a reactionary party to carry through reforms including the abolition of serfdom. However, as the narrator saw more of Court life and what went on behind the scenes, the aureole his imagination had surrounded the emperor with slowly faded, and by the end of the year he retained no illusions about useful activity in spheres nearest to the palace.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the narrator was supposed to report to the emperor every Sunday and what the colonel said about when to report otherwise.
response: As a sergeant, the narrator had to report to the emperor every Sunday at the parade in the riding-school that 'all was well at the company of the Corps of Pages,' even when one-third of the school was ill with a contagious disease. When the narrator asked if he should report that all was not quite well, the colonel replied that he ought only to say so if there were an insurrection.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the fate of the Sunday schools that were opened after the abolition of serfdom in Russia.
response: After the abolition of serfdom, Sunday schools were opened everywhere by private persons and corporations with volunteer teachers. Peasants and workers flocked to these schools, and effective teaching methods allowed peasants to learn to read in nine or ten lessons. However, all Sunday schools were suddenly closed, despite the fact that they would have taught the mass of peasantry to read in a few years without any state expenditure.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what role did Empress Marie Alexándrovna play in Russian reforms and education?
response: The empress played a part in bringing about the abolition of serfdom, though this was little known at the time. She was better known for her decisive role in creating girls' gymnasia (high schools), which had high standards and a democratic character. Her friendship with the pedagogist Ushínsky saved him from exile. She also worked hard to give her eldest son a good education, seeking the best teachers in all branches of knowledge.

instruction: Using only the passage, contrast the characters of the two brothers Nikolái Alexándrovich and Alexander Alexándrovich (later Alexander III).
response: Nikolái Alexándrovich was extremely handsome, not proud, and would chat in a comradelike way with pages de chambre, though those who knew him well described him as profoundly egoistic and incapable of forming attachments. Alexander Alexándrovich was a decided contrast—he reminded the author of Paul I in face, figure, and contemplation of his own grandeur. He obstinately refused to learn and was reportedly averse to any education from childhood.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what accusations did Katkóff make after the fire, and what was his motivation?
response: Katkóff, described as an ex-Whig inspired by personal hatred of Hérzen and especially Bakúnin (with whom he had once nearly fought a duel), accused the Poles and Russian revolutionists of causing the fire on the very day after it occurred.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what Senator Zhdánoff discovered during his inquiry and what happened to his findings.
response: Senator Zhdánoff was sent by the Tsar to investigate fires in Vólga towns, especially Sarátoff. He returned with the firm conviction that the Sarátoff conflagration was the work of the reactionary party. It was rumored he had positive proofs of the reactionaries' culpability, but he died on his way back, his portfolio disappeared, and it was never found.

instruction: According to the passage only, what were the consequences of the Apráxin fire on Russian society and government policy?
response: After the fire, Alexander II surrendered to the reactionaries. Public opinion in St. Petersburg and Moscow turned against both the advanced and moderate reform parties. 'The Contemporary' and similar reviews were suppressed, Sunday schools were prohibited, wholesale arrests began, and the capital was placed under a state of siege. It became improper to talk of reforms, and the atmosphere became laden with reactionary spirit.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was Kropotkin's general view on small communal experiments as a means of achieving anarchist society?
response: Kropotkin was highly skeptical about the chances of success for small and isolated communal experiments. He generally believed them to be a drain upon the energies of the anarchist movement, though he was not emotionally opposed to such ventures.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the New Australia Movement was and who originated it.
response: The New Australia Movement was a proposal for healthy and intelligent men and women to leave Australia and establish Co-operative Settlements on Socialistic principles in South America (Argentina). The idea originated with Mr Lane, editor of the best Socialistic labor paper in Queensland.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the editor say was a common misrepresentation of Kropotkin's vision of society?
response: Many commentaries misrepresent Kropotkin as having a vision of society consisting of unfederated and independent village-like settlements and as advocating small communal experiments as a means of achieving an anarchist society. The passage indicates this is a misrepresentation of his actual views.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author believe is the best location for starting a Communist Colony and why?
response: The author believes the best spot for a Communist Colony is near London or Paris. The reasons include: the privations would be less than in remote places like Argentina, the colony would not be cut off from the civilised world, and colonists would have access to lectures, good music, libraries, and could remain in contact with Communists doing propaganda work.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the type of agriculture the author recommends for a colony near a big city.
response: The author recommends intensive gardening and most intensive culture combined with handicraft, rather than agriculture practiced 2000 years ago. This includes growing all sorts of vegetables and possibly attempting intensive culture of wheat, guided by experienced real gardeners and advice from neighbours. This approach could provide nearly all the colony's food and pay the rent.

instruction: According to the passage only, what organizational elements does the author say a Communist colony should avoid, and what example does he give of people who live without such elements?
response: The author says a Communist colony should have no directors, no superintendents, no balloting, and no voting whatsoever, as these and the intrigues they cause have always been stumbling blocks for colonies. He gives the example of Russian peasants in a village mir who settle in Siberia, live without authority, agree at meetings for common work, and arrive at unanimity in their decisions without rulers or ballots.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how the author characterizes the cycle of human thought throughout history.
response: The author compares the history of human thought to a pendulum swinging over centuries. After long periods of slumber, thought awakens and frees itself from chains imposed by rulers, lawyers, and clerics. It criticizes established teachings and creates new sciences. However, enemies of thought (government, lawgiver, priest) eventually recover, adapt their codes to new needs, and regain control primarily through childhood education and fear, causing thought to slumber again until the next awakening.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the author says rulers and priests regain control over society after periods of intellectual awakening.
response: They gather their scattered forces and remodel their faith and laws to adapt to new needs. They take advantage of the servility they have cultivated, society's momentary disorganization, and people's laziness, greed, and hopes. Most importantly, they take possession of childhood through education, coercing children's weak spirits through fear by describing torments of hell and horrors of revolution, making children timid and obedient to both divine and civil law.

instruction: According to the passage only, what happens to morality during periods of social 'slumber' versus periods of awakening?
response: During slumbrous periods, morals are rarely discussed. Religious practices and judicial hypocrisy replace genuine moral discourse. People follow habit and indifference rather than critically examining established morality, and lying becomes virtue while enriching oneself becomes the watchword. During awakenings, youth frees itself from prejudices and begins to criticize. The question of morality comes up again, and paradoxically, when people are criticizing and denying conventional morality, moral sentiment actually makes the most progress—it grows, is raised, and refined.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what philosophical concepts does the speaker criticize as mere words invented to conceal ignorance?
response: The speaker criticizes concepts like the 'categoric imperative,' 'Providence,' and 'Destiny' as mere words invented to conceal ignorance.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the banner or philosophy that the youth of Russia unfurled when they broke with old-world prejudices.
response: They unfurled the banner of nihilist or anarchist philosophy: to bend the knee to no authority whatsoever, however respected, and to accept no principle so long as it is unestablished by reason.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did the nihilist youth develop after rejecting the moral teachings of their fathers?
response: They developed in their midst a nucleus of moral customs that was infinitely superior to anything their fathers had practiced under the control of the Gospel, Conscience, Categoric Imperative, or the utilitarian concept of Recognized Advantage.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain how the passage describes the motivation behind a woman giving away her last piece of bread to a stranger.
response: According to the passage, when a woman gives her last bread to a stranger, she does so because she would suffer infinitely more seeing a hungry person than feeling hungry herself. She escapes a pain that only those who have felt it know the intensity of.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the Russian nihilist martyr views her life compared to that of a petty scoundrel.
response: The passage states that even near the gallows, the martyr would say she would not exchange her life or death for that of the petty scoundrel. In her struggle against monstrous might she finds her highest joys, while the little joys and troubles of the bourgeois seem contemptible, tiresome, and pitiable to her. She would say 'You do not live, you vegetate; I have lived.'

instruction: According to the passage only, what example is given of animals acting on compassion stronger than personal security?
response: The passage describes a troupe of monkeys that, after seeing one of their members shot by a hunter, besieges his tent to claim the body despite the threatening gun. The Elder monkey goes in, threatens then implores the hunter, and through lamentations convinces him to give up the corpse. They obey a feeling of compassion stronger than all considerations of personal security.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what is described as the general line of action of the organic world?
response: The general line of action of the organic world is to seek pleasure and to avoid pain. The passage notes that some would call this a law, and states that without this quest of the agreeable, life itself would be impossible.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the 'egoistic theory' essentially claims about human actions.
response: The egoistic theory essentially claims that whatever a person's actions may be, they act in obedience to a craving of their nature. Whether actions are repulsive, indifferent, or attractive, they are all dictated by the individual's need, as the person acts because they find pleasure in it or avoid (or think they avoid) pain.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author say has been conquered by reaching the general conclusion about human motivation?
response: The author says that by reaching this general conclusion, we have conquered a truth and destroyed a prejudice which lies at the root of all prejudices. The author also states that all materialist philosophy in its relation to man is implied in this conclusion.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why the author believes anarchists have the right to use force against tyrants or exploiters.
response: The author argues that anarchists earn the right to use force because they would demand the same treatment for themselves if they became tyrants or exploiters. They would ask to be killed if they invaded others who did no harm, to be dispossessed if they exploited others, or to be slain if they became like a dethroned tyrant. This self-consistency and willingness to be held to the same standard gives them moral authority to act against oppressors.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the example of Perovskaya and her comrades illustrates the author's argument about the right to use force.
response: Perovskaya and her comrades killed the Russian Czar, and despite general repugnance to bloodshed and sympathy for the Czar who freed the serfs, mankind recognized their right to act. This was because people understood they would never become tyrants themselves - it was not palace conspiracy or an attempt to gain power, but hatred of tyranny carried to the point of scorning self and accepting death. They had 'conquered the right to kill' through their principles.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author say will happen if an act of force is committed without having 'conquered the right' to use it?
response: The author states that without conquering the right to use force, such an act - whether useful or not - will remain merely a brutal fact of no importance in the progress of ideas. People will see it as nothing but a displacement of force, simply the substitution of one exploiter for another.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain how the author's feelings about Jack the Ripper change when considering the broader context of society.
response: Initially, the author feels hatred toward Jack the Ripper for murdering poor, miserable women. However, when reflecting on the infamies that brought him to this state—the darkness he prowls in, haunted by images from indecent books—the feeling becomes divided. When imagining Jack in the hands of a judge who has killed far more people in cold blood in the name of law, the hatred for Jack vanishes entirely and transforms into hatred for the cowardly, hypocritical society and its representatives.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what the author believes impedes the free development of love and hate in present society.
response: The author identifies several things that impede the free development of love and hate: the State, the church, exploitation, judges, priests, governments, and exploiters. These elements are said to pervert our judgment and must be eliminated for moral sentiments to develop freely.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does the author say we express our moral feelings in daily life, and what does the author predict will happen when equal relations are established?
response: In daily life, we express sympathy or antipathy through our words, looks, and smiles—showing joy at actions useful to humanity and repugnance toward cowardice, deceit, intrigue, and lack of moral courage. The author predicts that when equal relations are established, the lying appearances we use to hide our contempt will vanish, and a loftier moral conception will arise in society.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the anarchist morality of equality refuse to do to the individual?
response: The anarchist morality of equality refuses to assume the right to mutilate the individual in the name of any ideal. It recognizes the full and complete liberty of the individual and desires for them plentitude of existence and free development of all faculties, wishing to impose nothing upon them.

instruction: According to the passage only, how should one respond to a person who deceives their friends?
response: Rather than rushing to embrace them or cordially shaking hands, one should be frank and vigorously oppose their active passion with one's own social passions. The passage states we have the right to express our sympathies and antipathies toward what seems good or bad, and it is our character to despise liars.

instruction: Using only the passage, what does the text say would happen if societies knew only the principle of equality as mere equity?
response: The passage states that if each person practiced merely the equity of a trader, taking care not to give others anything more than they received, society would die of it and the very principle of equality would disappear from our relations. Something grander than mere equity must perpetually find a place in life.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what Kropotkin says mankind admires in a truly moral person.
response: Mankind admires in a truly moral person their energy and exuberance of life, which urges them to give their intelligence, feeling, and action without asking for anything in return.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does Kropotkin argue happens when 'fecundity of will' is accompanied by poverty of feeling and an intellect incapable of creation?
response: It will produce nothing but figures like Napoleon I or Bismarck—wiseacres who try to force the world to progress backwards.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does Kropotkin say is required for life to be truly fruitful?
response: For life to be truly fruitful, it must be fertile at once in intelligence, in feeling, and in will. This fertility in every direction is life and the only thing worthy of the name.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what happens to a person who repeatedly acts against their ideal.
response: According to the passage, being untrue to your ideal repeatedly will paralyze your will and active energy. You will no longer regain the vigor and spontaneity of decision you formerly knew, becoming a broken person. The intensity of your life will decrease, and you will become a sick person without will, no longer the complete, strong, vigorous being you were when your acts accorded with your ideal conceptions.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe what the new morality being shaped will be like and how it will treat individuals.
response: The passage states this new morality will issue no commands and will refuse to model individuals according to an abstract idea or mutilate them by religion, law, or government. It will leave individuals full and perfect liberty. Rather than commanding, it will be a simple record of facts, a science, that presents choices to people based on their own strength and energies.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the science of morality advise for those who feel the strength of youth and wish to live fully?
response: The passage advises such people to be strong, great, and vigorous in all they do. They should sow life around them and avoid deceiving, lying, intriguing, or cheating, as these actions demean and belittle oneself. When they see unrighteousness, inequity, lies, or injustice, they should rise in revolt against it. To struggle is to live, and the fiercer the struggle, the intenser the life.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the common objection to Communism that the author addresses.
response: The common objection is that men are not good enough to live under Communism. Critics argue that centuries of individualistic education have made people too egotistic, and that slavery and submission have rendered them unfit for a society based on freedom and voluntary engagement. Therefore, some claim an intermediate transition state is necessary before achieving free, Anarchistic Communism.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how does the author counter the argument that people are not good enough for Communism?
response: The author counters by asking if men are good enough for Capitalism. He argues that if people were truly good, capitalism would pose no danger since capitalists would share profits and workers wouldn't exploit each other. Since people are not good enough, they should not continue under a system that permits oppression and exploitation. The current system actually encourages bad behavior like slavishness and egotism.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author propose as the means to make people less rapacious, egotistic, and slavish?
response: The author proposes eliminating the conditions which favour the growth of egotism, rapacity, slavishness, and ambition. Specifically, he advocates for higher instruction and equality of conditions as the only means for destroying inherited slavish instincts, rather than maintaining inequality of wealth, education, and knowledge.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the key difference between the author's view and that of their opponents regarding human nature and authority.
response: The author maintains that both rulers and ruled are spoiled by authority, and both exploiters and exploited are spoiled by exploitation. Their opponents, however, seem to believe there is a kind of 'salt of the earth' - the rulers, employers, and leaders - who prevent the ruled and exploited from becoming worse. The key difference is that the author makes no exception for rulers when admitting human imperfections, while opponents do make such an exception.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what did 'practical people' predict would happen after the abolition of slavery in America, and what actually occurred?
response: Practical people predicted that if Negroes were no longer compelled to work by whips, they would not work at all and would become a charge upon the community. They advocated for gradual emancipation with some form of whip maintained. However, after slavery was abolished without any transition period following the civil war, none of the terrible consequences they foresaw occurred. The Negroes proved to be industrious, laborious, and provident.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what the 'unpractical' camp proposed for Russian serfs and what the outcome was.
response: The unpractical camp proposed complete liberation of serfs, immediate abolition of any obligation of serfs towards lords, immediate abolition of the lord's jurisdiction, and transfer of affairs to peasants' tribunals elected by peasants who would judge according to unwritten customs rather than formal law. Despite being called folly by practical people, the scheme was largely implemented. Everything went smoothly, and the serfs displayed such good sense and organizing capacity that within three years the villages had completely changed - the slaves were becoming men.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the jurist Dallois observed about the relationship between ignorance in society and the multiplication of laws.
response: Dallois observed that when ignorance reigns in society and disorder exists in people's minds, laws are multiplied because legislation is expected to solve everything. Each fresh law becomes a fresh miscalculation, leading people to continually demand from law what can only proceed from themselves, their own education, and their own morality.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how education and upbringing contribute to society's dependence on law according to Kropotkin.
response: Kropotkin argues that education from infancy seeks to kill the spirit of revolt and develop submission to authority. Parents raise children in a moral atmosphere emphasizing respect for law and obedience to authority, while schools confirm this impression by using spurious science to prove the necessity of law. Obedience to law is made a religion, fusing moral goodness with the law of masters into a single divinity.

instruction: According to the passage only, what examples does Kropotkin give of people demanding laws instead of taking direct action to solve problems?
response: Kropotkin gives several examples: a peasant demands a law about parish roads when a road is impassable; an insulted person demands a law for politeness from park-keepers; farmers and speculators call for protective legislation when there is stagnation in agriculture or commerce; and when employers lower wages or increase hours, people demand a law instead of workers recovering wealth from employers through more effectual means.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the peasants initially accepted the principle of 'equality before the law' despite its limitations.
response: Peasants accepted 'equality before the law' because, having previously been treated worse than beasts with no rights or justice against nobles, they saw this principle as recognizing them as equals to their lords, at least in theory regarding personal rights. Though the promise was a lie, it represented an advance and a homage to justice compared to the arbitrary authority and violence they had endured before.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how the middle class used the concept of law after the French Revolution.
response: The middle class accepted law as a 'dyke to dam up the popular torrent' and worked to strengthen the principle upon which their power depended. They preached the doctrine in schools, propagated it in writings, molded art and science to support it, and thrust their beliefs everywhere. This allowed them to maintain control while promoting 'respect for law, the same for every man' and representative government as the philosophy of the bourgeois age.

instruction: According to the passage only, what distinguishes the modern rebels' approach to law from previous attitudes?
response: Modern rebels no longer wish to obey law without knowing its origins, uses, and the basis for the obligation to submit to it. They criticize the very foundations of society, analyzing law's sources and finding either a god born of savage terrors or bloodshed and conquest. They study law's characteristics and find immobility rather than growth, a tendency to crystallize what should be modified daily. This fundamental criticism makes the coming upheaval a Revolution rather than a mere insurrection.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the origin of Anarchism according to the text.
response: Anarchism owes its origin to two sources: the constructive, creative activity of the people which developed all institutions of communal life in the past, and a protest or revolt against external forces that thrust themselves upon these institutions. The aim was to give new scope to the people's creative activity so they could work out necessary institutions with fresh vigor.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how did the Christian movement's relationship to Anarchism change over time?
response: The Christian movement against Roman law, government, and morality initially contained much that was essentially Anarchistic. However, it gradually degenerated into an ecclesiastical movement modeled on the ancient Hebrew church and Imperial Rome, which killed the Anarchistic germ. It assumed Roman governmental forms and eventually became the chief bulwark of government authority, slavery, and oppression.

instruction: According to the passage only, what distinguishes Anarchism from other forms of Socialism?
response: While some socialists reached the negation of Capital and social organization based on labor exploitation but went no further, Anarchism extends its criticism further. Anarchism attacks not only Capital but also the main sources of Capitalism's power: Government and its chief supports including centralization, law (written by a minority in their interest), and Courts of justice (established mainly to defend Authority and Capital).

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the French eighteenth-century philosophers approached the study of moral phenomena differently from Kant.
response: The French philosophers endeavored to explain moral concepts like good and evil by studying living humans and tracing moral sentiments to simpler facts, such as the feeling of pity and sympathy. They avoided vague metaphysical terms. Kant, in contrast, explained the moral sense through the "categorical imperative" - a concept the passage criticizes as using vague verbal substitutes rather than explaining material facts.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe what Laplace accomplished in his 'System of the World' regarding metaphysics and scientific reasoning.
response: Laplace wrote his 'System of the World' without mentioning God or resorting to metaphysical entities. He avoided vague words that conceal unclear understanding of phenomena. His reasoning was so rigorous and his expression so lucid that mathematicians could later express every thought in the book as exact mathematical equations in terms of measurable quantities.

instruction: According to the passage only, how did the philosophers described trace the origin of moral sentiments in humans?
response: They traced moral sentiments to the feeling of pity (sympathy) and man's ability to put himself in another's place. They observed that humans almost feel pain and grow indignant when witnessing harm to others, such as a child being beaten. From these simple observations of common facts, they gradually attained broader generalizations about the complex moral sense.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain where the author believes a 'man of action' should be during revolutionary moments.
response: The author argues that the man of action's place is where the masses are. Whether carrying out individual acts like responding to police brutality, rebelling against iniquity, or spreading propaganda among troops, such acts have more impact when done openly in the eyes of the masses, where the press will report on it and workers will discuss it in workshops.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe why anarchists are arrested during periods of mass agitation according to the author.
response: Governments arrest anarchists because they believe that when people are in the street and individual initiative is lacking among the marching masses, it is from the anarchists that initiative for a movement will come, not from the legalists. The author notes this happens before, during, and after revolutions, and anarchists should anticipate such arrests in advance.

instruction: According to the passage only, what typically happens in the days following a large popular demonstration?
response: The author states that while a movement in a big city hardly ever takes place on the day of a large popular demonstration, it is always a few days after such a demonstration that the movement starts. People count themselves, understand their strength, become offended by police brutality and enraged by bloodshed at peaceful demonstrations, and then prepare another demonstration - but before that day arrives, the revolution already breaks out.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what methods were used to suppress anarchism during the fifteen-month period described?
response: The passage describes multiple suppression methods: silencing the press, shooting people at point blank range in Guyana, deportation to Spanish islands, incarceration of thousands in Italy without proper legal proceedings, and starving women and children by having police pressure employers not to give work to anarchists.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how young people in schools responded to anarchist ideas compared to other forms of socialism.
response: Young people in schools had long been resistant to socialism that started gloriously but ended with limited reforms like an eight-hour law or state expropriation of railroads. However, they greeted anarchism as a new arrival, seeing in it a large and powerful conception of society that embraced all human relations and brought pride, force, and initiative of free men. Their best representatives were drawn to a concept showing how freeing the worker becomes freeing of man.

instruction: According to the passage only, what role did Tolstoy play in the spread of anarchist ideas?
response: Tolstoy spoke to the entire civilized world and showed in his responses to criticisms of his last book how not only Christians, but every intelligent person regardless of philosophy, must completely break with the state that organizes worker exploitation and refuse to participate in the crimes, economic exploitation, and military atrocities committed by every state.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the author identifies as the main cause of wealth inequality between the rich and the poor.
response: The author argues that the rich accumulate wealth not through their own labor, but by appropriating the product of others' labor. While working people exert themselves to produce by their own labor, figures like Rothschild devote themselves to accumulating what others produce. This is identified as the fundamental reason why some possess hundreds of millions while workers possess very little.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what were the key characteristics of the late 18th century epoch that the author describes?
response: The author describes this epoch as marked by an expansion of intelligence, prodigious development of natural sciences, pitiless examination of accepted prejudices, formation of a theory of Nature based on scientific observation and reasoning, criticism of political institutions from preceding ages, and a movement towards the ideal of Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did the Revolution of 1789 proclaim in the economic order, and what flaw does the author identify in this approach?
response: The Revolution proclaimed freedom of business transactions - the liberty to sell and buy freely, including selling one's labor to the highest bidder, with the State not interfering and competition determining success. The flaw the author identifies is that while liberty of contract was proclaimed, the contending parties were not equally matched. The powerful, armed with means inherited from their fathers, gained the upper hand over the weak, causing millions of poor to give in against a few rich.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the wealthy person's gold would not increase if locked away according to the text.
response: The passage states that gold does not grow like seed, so if someone locks up £100, after a year they will not find £110 in their drawer - the gold simply does not increase on its own.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how Socialism evolved in its approach to addressing exploitation.
response: Socialism first spoke in the name of Christian sentiment and morality, arguing Christians had no right to exploit their brethren. Later it spoke in the name of Governmentalism, calling on the State to protect the weak and aid workers' associations. Finally, between twenty to thirty years later, Socialism spoke in the name of the people through the International Working Men's Association, concluding that all accumulated wealth is the product of the labour of all generations.

instruction: According to the passage only, what argument does the text make about the value of inventions and buildings?
response: The passage argues that inventions and buildings derive their value from collective labor and context. A hall in Paris has value because of the city built by twenty generations of labor - the same hall in Siberia would be nearly worthless. Similarly, a patented machine contains the intelligence of five or six generations and only has value as part of broader progress - a lace-making machine sent to New Guinea would become valueless.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what is the formula from 1848 that resonated with the masses?
response: The formula was 'From each according to his abilities, to each according to his needs.' This went straight to the heart of the masses, who hoped to attain Communism through the Republic and universal suffrage.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the author distinguishes the 'free Communism' advocated from earlier forms of Communism.
response: The author distinguishes free Communism from 'monastic or barrack-room Communism formerly advocated.' Free Communism places products reaped or manufactured in common at the disposal of all, while leaving each person the liberty to consume them as they please in their own home.

instruction: According to the passage only, what is the key question on which different schools of Socialists are opposed to one another?
response: The key question is who should have the management of the common patrimony. Some desire authoritarian Communism, while others, like the author, declare in favour of anarchist Communism.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author argue is the fundamental problem with representative government?
response: The author argues it is absurd to take a certain number of men from the mass and entrust them with managing all public affairs, expecting them to make laws on every subject from armaments to street-sweeping. A thoughtful person would recognize they cannot fulfill such a task since they are unacquainted with most questions they must legislate on, and would either work in the dark or need to summon meetings where people decide for themselves, making the representative's office unnecessary.

instruction: According to the passage only, what alternative does the author suggest to representative government for making decisions?
response: The author suggests that if people have formed opinions on issues, they should communicate with their neighbours and send delegates to come to an understanding with other delegates on specific questions. However, people should reserve to themselves the right of taking ultimate decisions rather than entrusting delegates with making laws for them. This is how scientists and business men act when they need to reach agreement.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the author's view on whether the State is necessary for territorial defense and crime prevention.
response: For territorial defense, the author argues that armed people with good weapons are the surest rampart against foreign aggressors, noting that standing armies are always beaten by invaders and only popular risings can repulse them. Regarding crime, the author contends the State increases crimes by creating misery rather than diminishing them, and maintains prisons as nurseries of vice where people come out worse than when they entered.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain the author's view on what happens to morality when religions decline.
response: The author argues that while religions are declining, morality remains. Religions contain both primitive cosmogony and public morality, but when religions are discarded, the moral principles they contain should not be abandoned. Society cannot exist without moral rules and habits, so even without religion, public morality is maintained, developed, and raised to higher standards.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the four men's different responses to the drowning child and which one the author considers truly moral.
response: The first man does nothing, following selfish middle-class maxims. The second saves the child expecting divine reward, making him a shrewd calculator rather than moral. The third, a utilitarian, reasons about superior pleasures but remains an egotist. The fourth man, raised to feel one with humanity, leaps in by instinct without reflection, acting from natural impulse. The author considers only this fourth man truly moral, as he acts from habit and genuine feeling rather than calculation.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does the author believe people should be moralized?
response: The author believes people cannot be moralized by teaching moral catechisms, and that tribunals and prisons do not diminish vice but spread it. Instead, people should be moralized by placing them in circumstances that develop social habits and weaken antisocial ones. A morality that becomes instinctive through habit is the true and enduring morality.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain what Anarchist Communism maintains about individual liberty and economic liberty.
response: Anarchist Communism maintains that individual liberty is the most valuable conquest and seeks to extend it by giving it a solid basis through economic liberty. It argues that without economic liberty, political liberty is delusive.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the text says society should develop according to anarchist principles.
response: Society should develop freely from the simple to the composite through the free union of free groups, rather than being constructed from top to bottom or from the center to the circumference. This free organization should ascend from simple to complex according to mutual needs and tendencies.

instruction: According to the passage only, why does the text argue that Communism must be anarchist rather than authoritarian?
response: The passage argues that Communism cannot be authoritarian or parliamentary because the mass of people does not desire to trust itself again to any saviour and will seek to organize itself by itself. Authoritarian Communism implies government with even greater power than exists today, combining economic and political power, which failed to gain sufficient response from true friends of liberty.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how Kropotkin distinguished between 'the State idea' and 'the idea of government.'
response: According to the passage, Kropotkin believed that 'the State idea means something quite different from the idea of government' and that those who think otherwise are 'confusing' the two concepts. He saw them as distinct rather than interchangeable.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe Malatesta's definition of the State as presented in his essay Anarchy.
response: Malatesta defined the State as the sum total of political, legislative, judiciary, military and financial institutions through which management of affairs, control over personal behavior, and responsibility for personal safety are taken from the people and entrusted to others who make and enforce laws. In this sense, the word State means government, and abolition of the State describes the destruction of all political order based on authority.

instruction: Using only the passage, identify the two main currents among socialists regarding the State that the author describes.
response: The passage identifies two main currents: those who hope to achieve social revolution through the State by preserving and extending its powers for revolutionary purposes, and those who see the State as an obstacle to social revolution and the birth of a society based on equality and liberty, working to abolish the State rather than reform it.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the distinction the author makes between the State and Government.
response: The author argues that State and government are two concepts of a different order. While there can be no State without government, the State idea means something quite different. The State includes not only a power situated above society, but also territorial concentration and the concentration of many societal functions in the hands of a few. It implies new relationships between members of society that did not exist before, requiring mechanisms of legislation and policing to subject some classes to the domination of others.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what criticism does the author make of the German school's view of the State?
response: The author criticizes the German school for confusing State with Society. This confusion leads to the accusation that anarchists want to destroy society and advocate for permanent war of each against all. The author argues this view ignores historical advances showing that humans lived in societies for thousands of years before the State existed, that the State in Europe only dates to the sixteenth century, and that humanity's most glorious periods were when civil liberties and communal life had not yet been destroyed by the State.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the Roman Empire exemplified the State according to the author.
response: The Roman Empire was a State in the real sense, serving as the legist's ideal. Everything gravitated towards Rome: economic and military life, wealth, education, and religion. Laws, magistrates, legions, prefects and gods all came from Rome. The Senate and later the Caesar governed as all-powerful and omniscient. The Empire did not represent a confederation of fellow citizens but a herd of subjects under a single law imposed by Rome, with its unity and unitarian spirit admired by legists and authoritarians.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the scientific discovery that brought Kropotkin joy and how it changed his perspective.
response: Kropotkin discovered that the main lines of structure in Asia run from south-west to north-east, not from north to south or west to east. After experiencing the joy of this scientific revelation, he was filled with sorrow that such joys are available to so few people. He questioned whether he had the right to enjoy this knowledge alone and felt a higher duty to bring information to the mass of people rather than continue making new discoveries.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain how Kropotkin's conception of a new society developed during his time in Switzerland.
response: During his first stay in Switzerland, Kropotkin abandoned state-socialists due to fear of economic despotism, hatred of centralization, and love for individual and commune freedom. Later, during his second stay among intelligent workers of West Switzerland after imprisonment in Russia, his vision became clearer as a society of federated associations cooperating like railway companies or postal departments of separate countries. He compared this coming structure to medieval guilds and mutual relations that were worked out from below.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe Kropotkin's character as a revolutionist according to the author.
response: Kropotkin was described as an unusually humane and mild revolutionist. He was never an avenger but always a martyr, making sacrifices himself rather than imposing them on others, doing so in a way that made the sacrifice seem to cost him nothing. He was not vindictive, was simplicity personified, and laughed at the oaths and ceremonies of conspirators in dramas and operas. The author states none have been more disinterested or loved mankind more than he.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the general reaction in Russia and the civilized world when Alexander III died?
response: When Alexander III died, a general feeling of relief went through Russia and the civilized world at large.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what Nicholas II did when Zemstvo delegates asked for closer intercourse between the Emperor and provincial representation.
response: Instead of accepting their modest invitation, Nicholas II read before the Zemstvo representatives an insolent speech of reprimand written for him by Pobiedonostseff, expressing his intention of remaining an autocratic ruler of his subjects.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does the author characterize the thirteen years of Alexander III's reign (1881-1894)?
response: The author characterizes these thirteen years as perhaps the gloomiest portion in the nineteenth century history of Russia, marked by heavy, silent, crushing reaction against the ideas of Liberty, slowly crushing down all progressive reforms of Alexander II and turning everything including education into tools of general reaction.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how Malon was earning his living in Switzerland after the Commune insurrection.
response: Malon was earning his living as a basket-maker. He rented a small open shed outside of town on a hillside, where he worked while enjoying a view of the Lake of Neuchâtel. At night he wrote letters, a book on the Commune, and short articles for labour papers, which helped him become a writer.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the reaction when Malon received news about Pindy?
response: Malon was radiant when he received a letter revealing that Pindy was alive and in Switzerland. Nothing had been heard of Pindy since May 25 or 26 at the Tuileries, and he was supposed to be dead, but he had actually remained in concealment in Paris.

instruction: According to the passage, what explanation is given for the high level of intellectual development among the watchmaking population in the Jura hills?
response: The organization of the watch trade permitted men to know one another thoroughly and to work in their own houses, where they were free to talk. This freedom and close interaction explains why the level of intellectual development in this population was higher.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the intellectual development of the Jura watchmakers was higher than that of factory workers.
response: The organization of the watch trade allowed workers to know one another thoroughly and work in their own homes where they were free to talk. This independence, compared to factory workers who spent their lives in factories from early childhood, resulted in more originality and a higher level of intellectual development among the watchmakers.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how Bakúnin's influence was perceived among the Jura Federation members.
response: Bakúnin's influence was felt more as a moral personality than as an intellectual authority. His writings and sayings were not treated as texts to be obeyed. In discussions, members used their own individual arguments rather than citing Bakúnin's opinions as final authority. He was spoken of with love and in a spirit of comradeship, as a personal friend rather than an absent chief whose opinions made law.

instruction: According to the passage only, what aspects of the Jura Federation appealed to the author's feelings and led him to become an anarchist?
response: The equalitarian relations in the Jura Mountains, the independence of thought and expression developing among the workers, and their unlimited devotion to the cause appealed strongly to the author's feelings. After a week's stay with the watchmakers, these experiences settled his views on socialism and made him an anarchist.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why the Commune Government failed to achieve social reform according to the author.
response: The author states that the workers had no distinct ideas of social reform to impress upon their representatives, and the fact of being isolated from the masses and shut up in the Hôtel de Ville paralysed them, preventing the Commune Government from acting in that direction.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the method the International Workingmen's Association used to solve problems of practical sociology.
response: The Association appealed to the workers themselves rather than having educated members impose theoretical ideals. Questions raised at international congresses were studied by labour unions throughout Europe, discussed in local section meetings with knowledge of local needs, then brought to federation congresses, and finally submitted in elaborated form to international congresses. The structure of society was thus worked out from beneath, in both theory and practice.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did the author come to realize anarchism represents beyond a mode of action?
response: The author realized that anarchism represents more than a mere mode of action and conception of a free society—it is part of a philosophy, both natural and social, which must be developed using the same methods as natural sciences, based on solid induction applied to human institutions rather than metaphysical or dialectic methods.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the main conflict between social democrats and anarchists at the International Socialist congresses.
response: The main conflict was over organizational control of the European labour movement. Social democrats tried to bring all labour movements under one organization with a central committee (essentially the old general council of the International under a new name), while anarchists opposed this centralization and worked to preserve the autonomy of labour organizations, particularly in Latin countries.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the three independent lines of socialist development and what they evolved into.
response: The three lines originated with Saint-Simon, Fourier, and Robert Owen. Saint-Simonism developed into social democracy, Fourierism developed into anarchism, and Owenism developed in England and America into trade-unionism, co-operation, and municipal socialism. Owenism remains hostile to social democratic state socialism while sharing many points of contact with anarchism.

instruction: Using only the passage, what happened to the author at the Ghent congress and how did he escape?
response: Three or four days into the congress, Belgian police discovered the author's true identity (he was using the name Levashóff) and planned to arrest him for giving a false name at his hotel. Belgian friends warned him that the clerical ministry might hand him over to Russia. They prevented him from returning to his hotel, and comrades escorted him through dark squares with mysterious whistling and calls to a social democrat worker's home for the night. The next morning he left for England by steamer.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how Russia's industrial production changed between 1861 and 1894.
response: In 1861, Russia and Poland had 14,060 manufactories producing 296,000,000 roubles (about £36,000,000) yearly. By 1881, the number of establishments rose to 35,160 with production nearly quadrupling to 1,305,000,000 roubles (about £131,000,000). By 1894, aggregate production reached 1,759,000,000 roubles (£180,000,000), though this census excluded smaller manufactures and industries paying excise duties.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain what happened to production per worker in Russia's manufacturing sector and what caused this change.
response: Production per worker more than trebled in leading industries. The average was less than £70 per annum in 1861 but reached £219 by the time described. The passage states this increase in production was chiefly due to the improvement of machinery, not an increase in workers, as the number of workmen had not even doubled since 1861.

instruction: According to the passage only, how did foreign capital and expertise contribute to Russia's textile industry development?
response: Lancashire manufacturers began planting their mills in Russia. Two large mills for spinning the finest cotton yarn were opened in 1897 with English capital and engineers. A Manchester manufacturer opened a factory for making thin wire for cotton-carding in Moscow. For woollens, English, German and Belgian mill-owners built wool-combing, spinning and weaving mills with the best modern plant in Russia and Poland.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how Russia's domestic industries compare to its manufactures in terms of production value.
response: According to the passage, domestic industries occupy more than 7,500,000 peasants, and their aggregate production was estimated at more than the aggregate production of all the manufactures, exceeding £180,000,000 per annum.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the development of agricultural machinery manufacturing in Russia, particularly in the region near the Sea of Azov.
response: Agricultural machinery manufacturing developed significantly on the plains sloping towards the Sea of Azov. Vice-Consul Green reported in 1894 that the region was studded with small engineering works engaged in manufacturing agricultural machines, most having their own foundries. The town of Berdyansk had the largest reaper manufactory in Europe, capable of producing three thousand machines annually.

instruction: According to the passage only, what factors does the author suggest explain the decline of foreign imports into Russia better than protective duties?
response: The author argues that the decline of imports is much better explained by the growth of home industries rather than high protective duties. The passage notes that protective duties helped attract German and English manufacturers to Poland and Russia, who then established and improved industries within the country, including cotton manufactures, woollen industries, machinery production, and iron industry.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the industrial progress of Italy as mentioned.
response: Italy has grown to rank among manufacturing countries, as shown at the Turin Exhibition of 1884. There is a widespread effort to become self-sufficient, with the patriotic watchword being 'Italy all by herself.' Coal imports increased significantly (from 779,000 tons in 1871 to 9,339,000 tons in 1910), mining industries trebled production between 1870-1885, steel and machinery production reached £4,800,000 in 1900, and textile industries grew as shown by raw cotton imports and spindle numbers.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how did Brazil's cotton industry develop between 1870 and 1912?
response: In 1870, Brazil had only nine cotton mills with an aggregate of 385 spindles. By 1887, there were 46 cotton mills with nearly 10,000 looms producing over 33,000,000 yards of cotton stuffs annually, with five mills having 40,000 spindles. By 1912, Brazil had 161 cotton mills with 1,500,000 spindles and 50,000 looms, employing over 100,000 operatives.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how India contradicted the export theory regarding British cotton goods.
response: India was considered the surest customer for British cottons, buying nearly one-quarter to one-third of total British cotton exports (£17,000,000 to £22,000,000 out of about £75,000,000 in 1880-1890). However, this changed as Indian cotton manufactures developed. By 1904-1907, British exports to India were only £21,680,000 to £25,680,000 out of an aggregate of £110,440,000, representing a smaller proportion of total exports.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the growth of India's cotton manufacturing industry from 1860 to 1910.
response: India's cotton manufacturing grew significantly over this period. Raw cotton consumption increased from 23,000,000 lb. in 1860 to nearly four times that amount by 1877, then trebled again to 283,000,000 lb. by 1887-1888. Cotton mills grew from 40 in 1887 to 147 in 1895 and reached 237 by 1909-1910. Spindles increased from 886,100 to 3,844,300 between 1887-1895, reaching 6,136,000 by 1909-1910. Workers employed rose from 57,188 in 1887 to 146,240 seven years later, and to 231,850 by 1909-1910.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what factors does the author suggest would not prevent the growth of Indian manufactures?
response: The author argues that neither lack of capital nor lack of knowledge would prevent Indian manufacturing growth. Capital knows no fatherland and will migrate to India for high profits from workers whose wages are only half or less than English workers. Knowledge spreads regardless of location, with only the first steps being difficult. The author also notes that Hindu workers' capacities are not inferior to the young workers employed in British textile factories.

instruction: Using only the passage, summarize Japan's emergence as a competitor in cotton manufacturing.
response: Japan emerged as a powerful competitor within twenty years. In October 1888, Japan's annual cotton yarn production was 9,498,500 lb., with fifteen more mills holding 156,100 spindles under construction. By 1890, production reached 27,000,000 lb. While in 1887-1888 Japan imported five or six times as much yarn as it produced domestically, by the next year only two-thirds of consumption was imported. Production grew from 6,435,000 lb. in 1886 to 91,950,000 lb. in 1893 and 153,444,000 lb. thereafter.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what Adam Smith's view on low profits means for wages and consumption.
response: According to the passage, Adam Smith said that low profits ultimately mean a reduction of wages, and low wages mean reduced consumption by the worker. This creates a cycle where low profits also lead to somewhat reduced consumption by the employer, which together with reduced worker consumption means lower profits for the immense class of middlemen in manufacturing countries.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author argue 'over-production' actually means?
response: The author argues that over-production is a word utterly devoid of sense unless it means that those who need all kinds of produce do not have the means to buy them with their low wages. Over-production means merely and simply a want of purchasing powers amidst the workers.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the comparison made between Switzerland's economy and countries that manufacture for export.
response: The passage compares a country that manufactures for export to Switzerland, which lives largely on profits from tourists visiting her lakes and glaciers. Just as a good tourist 'season' brings money influx and a bad season causes general impoverishment like a bad crop, a manufacturing country suffers when exported goods cannot be sold abroad for twice their value at home. Low profits for Alpine innkeepers affect Switzerland similarly to how low profits for Lancashire and Scotch manufacturers affect Great Britain.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what happened to British cotton export values between 1883 and 1895.
response: In 1883, the United Kingdom exported 4,957,000,000 yards of piece goods and 316,000,000 lb. of yarn for an export value of £104,000,000. By 1895, despite exporting more goods (5,478,000,000 yards and 330,000,000 lb. of yarn), the export value actually decreased to only £99,700,000. This shows that Britain had to export greater quantities to earn less money.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how Britain's share of cotton industry spindles changed over time.
response: Britain's share of cotton spindles declined significantly over time. In 1880, Britain had about 55% of all spindles in Europe, the United States and India (40,000,000 out of 72,000,000). By 1893, this dropped to 49% (45,300,000 out of 91,340,000), and later the United Kingdom had only 41% of all spindles.

instruction: According to the passage only, what reasons are given for why Britain could not maintain its manufacturing dominance?
response: The passage explains that there was no reason Britain should always be the great cotton manufactory since raw cotton had to be imported into Britain just as elsewhere. It was natural for other countries like France, Germany, Italy, Russia, India, Japan, the United States, Mexico and Brazil to begin spinning their own yarns and weaving their own cotton. Additionally, the development of textile industries in these countries led to growth in related industries like chemical works, mechanical works, metallurgy and mining.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the contrast between land use near London and what Paris gardeners could achieve with the same land.
response: Within ten miles of Charing Cross, meadow land barely produced two tons of hay per acre, enough to keep only one milch cow per two acres, with man largely absent from cultivation. In contrast, Paris gardeners cultivating the same distance from their city would have at least 2,000 people working each thousand acres, producing vegetables worth £50 to £300 per acre.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what evidence does the author provide about the decline of rural population and agriculture in South Devon and Scotland?
response: In South Devon, the author observed abandoned cottages, orchards going to ruin, and fields covered only with short grass and thistles despite fertile soil and favorable climate. In Scotland, the rural population fell below 800,000 by 1911, agricultural laborers decreased by 42,370 between 1881-1901, land went out of culture, and former arable land was converted to deer forests for wealthy hunters.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author argue about the fertility of soils and human labor?
response: The author argues that in the hands of man there are no unfertile soils. He states that the most fertile soils are not in American prairies or Russian steppes, but in places like Irish peat-bogs, sand downs of northern France's sea-coast, and craggy Rhine mountains—all made fertile by human hands.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what are some of the causes mentioned that have led to the decline of intensive farming in Britain?
response: The passage lists several causes: concentration of land ownership among big landowners; high profits obtained previously; development of landlords and farmers who rely on other incomes and treat farming as a pleasant by-occupation or sport; rapid development of game reserves for sportsmen; absence of men of initiative to show the necessity of new methods; absence of desire to gain necessary knowledge; lack of institutions to spread practical agricultural knowledge and introduce improved seeds; and dislike of agricultural co-operation like that practiced by Danish farmers.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the passage contrasts British agriculture's reputation with its actual performance.
response: The passage acknowledges that British agriculture has a reputation for superiority, with crops averaging 28-30 bushels of wheat per acre compared to France's 17-20 bushels, and producing £200,000,000 worth of animal produce annually. However, it argues this reputation is misleading because only 1,600,000 to 1,900,000 acres out of 33,000,000 cultivable acres bear such crops, meadows are inferior in productivity to corn-fields, and fine cattle breeds require three acres each to be fed, showing poor land efficiency.

instruction: According to the passage only, what happened to agricultural laborers and land use in Scotland between 1881 and 1901?
response: The number of agricultural laborers decreased by 42,370 (from 135,970 to 93,600) during the twenty years from 1881 to 1901. The land went out of culture while the area under 'deer forests'—hunting grounds established on formerly arable land for the amusement of the rich—increased at an appalling rate, and the Scottish population was emigrating and depopulating rapidly.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how wheat production in France changed during the nineteenth century relative to population growth.
response: During the nineteenth century, France nearly doubled both the area under wheat and the returns from each acre, increasing the amount of wheat grown almost fourfold. Meanwhile, the population only increased by 41 percent, meaning the ratio of increase of the wheat crop was six times greater than the ratio of increase of population.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what obstacles hampered French agriculture during the nineteenth century?
response: French agriculture was hampered by taxation, military service, poverty of the peasantry, and up to 1884, a severe prohibition of all sorts of association among the peasants.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the agricultural situation on the island of Jersey.
response: Jersey is a small island about eight miles long and less than six miles wide with only 28,707 acres including rocks. It has about two inhabitants per acre (1,300 per square mile) and still practices open-field culture under Norman common law rather than Roman law and landlordism. The peasants achieve admirable results and well-being through rational and intensive culture on small farms of five to twenty acres, often less than five acres. The soil consists of decomposed granite with no organic matter.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what agricultural products are grown and exported from the Alpes Maritimes and Var départements in France.
response: The Alpes Maritimes département exported fresh flowers worth £400,000 yearly, plus flowers used for perfumes valued at £280,000 to £320,000. The Var département exported 3,475 tons of flowers valued at £160,000 to £200,000 in 1902.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain how Belgium has developed its horticultural industry.
response: Belgium's vegetable exports doubled in the last twenty years of the nineteenth century. Regions like Flanders became market-gardens for England. Sand deserts of the Ardennes and peat-bogs were turned into rich market-gardens, and large plains were irrigated. Communes, private societies, and the State opened schools, experimental farms, stations, and evening lectures. Hundreds of acres were covered with greenhouses. Some communes even maintained their own steamship lines for export.

instruction: Using only the passage, what evidence does the author provide to counter the idea that American fruit grows easily due to natural advantages?
response: The author argues that American horticulture has been brought to a high degree of perfection through effort, not just natural advantages. Prof. Baltet, a practical gardener, described Virginia's truck farms as model farms. The author notes Canadian experimental farms aid apple-growers and spread information to farmers on a large American scale. The passage states that if England did one tenth of what America and Canada do to favor agriculture and horticulture, English fruit would not have been driven from the market.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the productivity of Mr. Bashford's establishment in terms of crops and labor.
response: Mr. Bashford's establishment produced impressive yields including 25 tons of grapes yearly, 80 tons of tomatoes from 20,000 plants, 30 tons of early potatoes, 6 tons of early peas, and 2 tons of early French beans. All this was achieved with only 36 men and boys under the supervision of one gardener (the owner himself), using about 1,000 tons of coke for heating. The money returns from these 13 acres were equivalent to what a farmer would obtain from 1,300 acres.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what did Mr. Rider Haggard conclude about Jersey and Guernsey after his 1901 visit?
response: Mr. Rider Haggard gave an enthusiastic description of both islands and was amazed at their prosperity. He found it astonishing that such a small area of land could produce so much wealth. He cited an example of a 23⅓ acre patch that sold at auction for £5,760 for potato cultivation (not building sites). Like his predecessors, he also dispelled the legend of extraordinary natural soil fertility, showing that heavy potato crops required considerable expenditure.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what the author observed in the small vineries and greenhouses during his visits.
response: The author saw remarkable results in small vineries. In one ¾-acre heated greenhouse, about 8 tons of tomatoes and 200 lb of French beans were harvested as a first crop in April, with two more crops to follow, using one gardener with two assistants. In cool greenhouses, pea plants covering ¼ mile of walls had yielded 3,200 lb of peas by end of April. He also visited a tiny ⅔-acre vinery where a veteran grower produced exceptional grapes (one bunch weighing 13¾ lb sold for £4), along with impressive tomatoes and strawberries, demonstrating that half a ton of strawberries could be gathered from a small space under proper culture.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the two great branches of how workers in small industries sell their produce.
response: In one branch, the worker sells produce directly to the wholesale dealer, as seen with cabinet-makers, weavers, and toy trade workers. In the other branch, the worker works for a 'master' who either sells to a wholesale dealer or acts as a middleman receiving orders from a big concern - this is the 'sweating system' under which many small trades operate.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what are the different forms of workshop arrangements that exist between purely domestic trades and factories?
response: The passage describes several gradations: purely domestic work done at home by family members; a master keeping a small workshop attached to his house working with family or wage-workers; artisans with separate workshops supplied with wheel-power; workers coming together in small factories they maintain, hire in association, or rent; and big factories where workers pay for equipment use and receive piecework wages.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does weaving work operate in the textile trades under the small industry system?
response: Weaving is done either by the family or by a master employing one boy or several weavers. The master receives yarn from a big employer, pays a skilled workman to put yarn in the loom and invent what's necessary for weaving patterns. After weaving cloth or ribbons in his own or hired loom, he is paid according to a complicated wage scale agreed between masters and workers. This exists alongside big factories with wage-workers.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the structure of the ready-made clothing industry in terms of factory size and working conditions.
response: Ready-made clothing factories have averages of 80-150 persons per factory, but countless small workshops also exist alongside them. These factories have a special character: they buy cloth and do cutting with special machinery, but sewing is done by women who come to work in the factory. Workers pay for their sewing-machine, motor power, gas, and iron usage, and work on piece rates. This often becomes a 'sweating system' on a large scale, with many small workshops centered around the big factories.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what evidence does the author provide to show that small industries coexist with large ones in soap manufacturing?
response: The author notes that while there are half a dozen very large soap works known for their advertisements on cliffs and in fields, the low average of only twenty-nine workmen per factory proves how many small factories must exist alongside these 'soap kings.' The fabrication of soap and candles belongs almost entirely to the domain of small industry.

instruction: According to the passage only, how many factories employing more than 1,000 workpeople each exist in textile and non-textile industries, and how many workers do they employ?
response: Mr. Whitelegge reports that there are only sixty-five factories employing more than 1,000 workpeople each in textile industries (102,600 workpeople) and only 128 such factories in all non-textile industries (355,208 workpeople).

instruction: Based only on the passage, what were the two opposing political positions regarding petty trades in Germany?
response: Ultra-conservative elements tried to use petty trades and domestic industries to return to "olden good times" by passing laws to reintroduce old-fashioned closed corporations under State supervision, viewing this as a weapon against social democracy. On the other hand, social democrats opposed these measures and took the abstract view that "petty trades are in decay" and should disappear sooner to make room for capitalist centralisation, which they believed would achieve its own ruin.

instruction: According to the passage only, in what types of industries do petty trades have good chances of continuing to exist and develop?
response: Petty trades have good chances where direct intervention of taste and inventiveness are required, where new patterns of goods requiring continual renewal of machinery and tools must be introduced (such as fancy textiles), where great variety and uninterrupted invention of new goods occurs (like toy trade, instrument making, watch-making, bicycle making), and wherever the artistic feeling of the individual worker makes the best part of the goods (as in small articles of luxury).

instruction: Using only the passage, what years were the three censuses of industries conducted in Germany?
response: The three censuses of industries in Germany were conducted in 1882, 1895, and 1907.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author argue about comparing the conditions of workers in petty trades versus factory workers?
response: The author argues that when comparing the miserable conditions of workers in petty trades with factory workers in the same regions and trades, the very same misery prevails among factory workers. Factory workers live on wages of nine to eleven shillings a week in town slums, work eleven hours a day, and suffer during frequently recurring crises.

instruction: According to the passage only, what is identified as the main factor working against small industries in favor of factories?
response: The passage states that in an immense number of trades, it is not the superiority of technical organization or economies on the prime-motor that work against small industry, but rather the more advantageous conditions for selling produce and buying raw materials that are at the disposal of big concerns.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what happens when small industries overcome difficulties related to selling and buying through association or securing markets.
response: When these difficulties are overcome through association or by securing a market for sales, the conditions of workers or artisans immediately improve, and rapid progress is realized in technical aspects of the industries. This includes introducing new processes, inventing new machine-tools, resorting to new motors, or reorganizing the trade to diminish production costs.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why the author believes most students fail to retain geometry knowledge after leaving school.
