response: The young man is simply a traveler on his way to rejoin his father. He lost all his money to a card-playing captain at a post-station and cannot pay his inn bill or continue his journey. Because he has been staying at the inn for a fortnight without paying, doesn't travel further, and looked inquisitively at other guests' plates (due to hunger), the town's gossips Dóbchinsky and Bóbchinsky report him as suspicious, leading the Governor and officials to conclude he must be the incognito Inspector-General.

instruction: According to the passage only, what corrupt practices has the Governor engaged in before the Inspector-General's expected arrival?
response: The Governor has freely levied tribute upon the merchants, pocketed money that was destined for building a church, and flogged the wife of a non-commissioned officer (which he had no right to do). He also asks the postmaster to open and potentially withhold letters from the town to St. Petersburg that might contain reports about town matters.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the Inspector claim about onions?
response: The Inspector claims that he never touches onions, stating this upon his honour to the audience after Korobkin reads that the inspector of schools smells of onions.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the Judge's reaction to the French phrase 'mauvais ton' being read about him.
response: The Judge does not know what the phrase means. He says the deuce knows what it means, and comments that if it were only 'a robber' it would be all right, but it may be something worse.

instruction: According to the passage only, what announcement causes the curtain to drop at the end of the scene?
response: A police soldier enters and announces in a loud voice that a functionary from St. Petersburg with Imperial orders wants to see everyone immediately and is staying at the hotel. The curtain then drops over a living picture.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what made The Inspector-General significant in Russian dramatic art?
response: The Inspector-General marks a new era in Russian dramatic art. Unlike other comedies and dramas of the time which were imperfect and puerile, it would have marked an epoch in any language at its appearance in 1835. Its stage qualities, sound and hearty humour, natural comical scenes resulting from the characters themselves, and sense of measure make it one of the best comedies in existence.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why Gógol never finished his comedy The Vladimir Cross.
response: The Inspector-General provoked such a storm of hostile criticism from reactionary Russia that it was hopeless to expect The Vladimir Cross, concerning the life of St. Petersburg functionaries, could ever be admitted on the stage. Gógol never finished it, only publishing a few striking scenes from it such as The Morning of a Busy Man and The Law Suite.

instruction: According to the passage only, what is the plot of Gógol's comedy Marriage and why does it remain relevant?
response: Marriage represents the hesitation and terror an inveterate bachelor goes through before a marriage, which he finally eludes by jumping out of a window moments before the ceremony begins. It has not lost its interest because it is so full of comical situations that fine actors appreciate, and it remains part of the current repertoire of the Russian stage.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the character of Tchítchikoff and what makes him remarkable in social situations.
response: Tchítchikoff is a middle-aged man, not too thick and not too thin, who moves with almost military lightness. He is remarkable for his ability to speak knowledgeably on any topic - whether government inquests, billiards, virtue, brandy, or customs officers. Most notably, he covers everything with propriety and always knows how to behave appropriately. He never speaks too loudly or too softly, but exactly as one ought to speak. He adapts his conversation to suit whoever he's speaking with, whether an old general or a sentimental reformer, always keeping his true objectives in view.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why the author considers Tchítchikoff to be more than just a Russian type.
response: The author argues that Tchítchikoff is an immortal international type rather than just a Russian one. The passage states that everyone has met someone like him, and that we meet him everywhere - he is of all lands and of all times. He simply takes different forms to suit the requirements of nationality and time. Whether he buys dead souls, railway shares, collects charitable funds, or seeks a bank position, his essential character remains universal.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe Maníloff's character and his relationship with his wife.
response: Maníloff appears very nice at first, but his features seem to have too much sugar in them. After initial conversation, people find him pleasant, then uncertain about him, and eventually feel mortally bored. He has no particular enthusiasm or point of interest and remains in a mild temper, lost in vague reflections about impractical ideas like underground passages and stone bridges with shops. His household always has something missing, like chairs covered in sackcloth instead of silk. He and his wife are quite satisfied with each other after eight years of marriage, still exchanging small affections like sharing sweets and giving each other long kisses spontaneously.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the traditional religious view of human morality was represented and how this view evolved over time.
response: Traditionally, human action was explained as a struggle between a devil on one shoulder prompting evil and an angel on the other encouraging virtue. As these beliefs faded, the essential idea remained but was disguised in philosophical terms: 'the flesh' or 'passions' replaced the devil, while 'conscience,' 'soul,' or 'reflection of divine thought' replaced the angel. Human virtue was still measured by how well the soul/conscience triumphed over flesh/passions.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the controversial claim made by English philosophers and later thinkers like Bentham and John Stuart Mill about human motivation?
response: They claimed that the devil and angel had nothing to do with human action, and that all human acts—whether good or bad, useful or harmful—arise from a single motive: the lust for pleasure (egoism). This assertion was met with accusations of immorality, insults, excommunication, and their books were banned by conspiracy of silence.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how Kropotkin argues that both selfish and virtuous acts share the same underlying motive.
response: Kropotkin argues that both the man who snatches bread from a child and the man who shares his last bread with the hungry act from the same motive: the quest for pleasure. The virtuous man gives because he finds pleasure in giving; if he found pleasure in taking from a child, he would do that instead. Both actions stem from seeking pleasure or avoiding pain, despite their different results for humanity.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how theologians and metaphysical philosophers have traditionally explained the human ability to distinguish between good and evil.
response: Theologians (Mosaic, Buddhist, Christian, and Mussulman) have attributed the ability to distinguish good from evil to divine inspiration. Metaphysical philosophers have explained it through concepts like conscience or a mystic 'imperative,' but according to the passage, they essentially just changed the terminology without offering a fundamentally different explanation.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the examples given of how animals demonstrate moral behavior in their societies.
response: The passage provides several examples: 1) Ants with full crops share honey with hungry ants, and selfish ants who refuse are treated more harshly than enemies. 2) Sparrows notify others when food is available and punish those who steal nesting materials by pecking them. 3) Marmots quarrel with members who refuse to share access to underground storehouses with others in their colony.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author argue is the true basis for conceptions of good and evil?
response: The author argues that good and evil are based on what is useful or hurtful for the preservation of the race (not the individual). This is described as a natural need of animal races rather than something derived from religion or mystic conscience. What benefits society is considered good, and what harms it is considered bad.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what examples does the author give of people who embody the spirit of devotion and courage?
response: The author gives several examples: the ardent revolutionist who cannot enjoy art, science, or family life while others cannot share them; the youth who joins a volunteer corps after hearing of invasion atrocities and dies in battle; the Paris street arab who defended the ramparts with his little brother and died saying 'Long live the Commune'; the person who stands up against wrongs and unmasks exploiters; and the countless acts of devotion, especially among women, that form the foundation of human life.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does the author explain the concept of moral 'obligation' or duty?
response: The author, citing the anarchist philosopher Guyau, explains that moral duty is nothing but a superabundance of life which demands to be exercised and given. It is the consciousness of a power. The condition of maintaining life is its expansion - accumulated force creates pressure to act, so power to act becomes duty to act. Like a plant that cannot prevent itself from flowering even if it means death, humans full of force and energy must expand their life and give without calculation.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author believes religions have remained alive despite the passage of time.
response: The author states that religions are still alive because, apart from ignorance, they have always appealed to devotion and courage. Religions have sought to appropriate the courage and devotion that exists in every age among people, turning it into current coin for their own benefit.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author believes mechanical phenomena are sufficient for explaining nature.
response: The author states that mechanical phenomena, in their ever-increasing complexity, suffice for explaining nature and the whole of organic and social life. While acknowledging there is much still unknown, the author sees no domain where mechanical phenomena (like those observed in a falling stone, billiard ball impacts, or chemical reactions) would prove inadequate for necessary explanations.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was Auguste Comte's main weakness when he moved from exact sciences to studying social institutions?
response: According to the passage, Comte proved weak when studying social institutions because he had not addressed the most important point: the origin of the moral principle in man. He needed to explain this principle using the same phenomena he used to explain life in general, and to show why humans feel compelled to obey their moral sense. However, he lacked the necessary knowledge to do this at the time he wrote.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what characteristics the author says a synthetic philosophy should have.
response: The author states a synthetic philosophy should: no longer discuss 'the essence of things,' 'first causes,' or 'the aim of life'; repudiate anthropomorphism; be a digest and unification of all knowledge; proceed from simple to complex; furnish a key to understanding all nature; indicate lines of further research; provide means of discovering new correlations (laws); and inspire confidence in conclusions even when they differ from current superstitions.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why Comte created the concept of Humanity as a new idol in his philosophy.
response: Comte created Humanity as a new idol because he would not admit that everything moral in man grew out of observation of nature and from the conditions of men living in societies. He did not see that moral sentiment was deeply rooted in man's physical constitution inherited from slow evolution, originating in animal societies before humans existed. Therefore, he felt compelled to invent Humanity as something outside and higher than the individual to constantly recall man to the moral path.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what scientific developments occurred during 1856-1862 that changed views on nature?
response: During 1856-1862, scientists including Grove, Clausius, Helmholtz, Joule, and Kirchhoff proved the unity of nature throughout the inorganic world. Kirchhoff discovered spectroscopic analysis, enabling determination of distant stars' composition. It was shown that mechanical motion of molecules could explain all phenomena of heat, light, electricity, and magnetism, eliminating the need for mysterious imponderable fluids. These same molecular vibrations were found adequate to explain chemical phenomena as well.

instruction: According to the passage only, how did Comte's Christian education influence his philosophical approach to morality?
response: Comte's Christian education led him to revert to Christian ideas when facing questions of morality. Christianity cannot be conceived without a struggle between evil and good principles and without man's application in prayer to the good principle for maintaining virtue. Dominated from childhood by this Christian idea, Comte paid tribute to his Christian education by creating a system requiring homage to something higher than the individual (Humanity) to keep man on the moral path, similar to how Christianity functions.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what are the three types of autobiographies that great minds produced in former times according to the preface?
response: The three types are: 1) 'So far I went astray, thus I found the true path' (exemplified by St. Augustine); 2) 'So bad was I, but who dares to consider himself better!' (exemplified by Rousseau); 3) 'This is the way a genius has slowly been evolved from within and by favourable surroundings' (exemplified by Goethe).

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the key similarities between Tolstoy and Kropotkin as outlined in the preface.
response: Both are filled with love for mankind and severely condemn the indifference, thoughtlessness, crudeness and brutality of the upper classes. Both feel attracted to the life of downtrodden people, see more cowardice than stupidity in the world, are idealists with reformer's temperaments, and are peace-loving natures. Both also abandoned their original paths—Tolstoy due to religious considerations and Kropotkin due to social considerations.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does Kropotkin's autobiography differ from typical autobiographies in terms of self-representation?
response: Kropotkin is not preoccupied with his own capacities or the opinions of fellow-men about himself. He does not gaze upon his own image, speaks of himself reluctantly and with shyness, offers no confession of his inner self, no sentimentality or cynicism. He mentions neither sins nor virtues, avoids vulgar intimacy with readers, and is more anxious to give the psychology of his contemporaries and the history of Russia than his own story.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the key differences between Tolstoy and Kropotkin regarding their attitudes toward educated people and science.
response: Tolstoy, in his religious passion, disdains and disparages both the intelligent educated man and science altogether. Kropotkin, in contrast, holds both in high esteem, although he condemns men of science for forgetting the people and the misery of the masses.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what scientific discovery did Kropotkin make about the geography of Asia?
response: Kropotkin discovered that the maps of Northern Asia were incorrect and that the main structural lines of Asia run from the south-west to the north-east, rather than from north to south or west to east as previously believed, including contradicting Humboldt's theories.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the contrasting social positions and experiences Kropotkin had throughout his life.
response: Kropotkin moved through all layers of society. He was a little boy in fancy dress standing by Emperor Nicholas and served as a page to Emperor Alexander. He lived as an aristocrat and as a worker, was one of the Emperor's pages and a poverty-stricken writer. He experienced life as a student, officer, man of science, explorer, administrator, and hunted revolutionist. He lived in the highest Russian society and in poverty with the working proletariat, and was confined in terrible prison conditions.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the main goal of the young people who formed small groups for self-improvement in Russian towns?
response: The aim of their reading and discussion was to solve the question of how they could be useful to the masses. They gradually concluded that the only way was to settle amongst the people and live the people's life.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what professions or roles young women took on when they went to the villages.
response: Girls passed teachers' examinations, learned midwifery or nursing, and went into the villages by the hundred. They devoted themselves entirely to the poorest part of the population, wanting to teach peasants to read, instruct them, give medical help, and aid in raising them from darkness and misery.

instruction: According to the passage only, what were the characteristics of Dmítri Kelnitz and his approach to work?
response: Kelnitz was very intelligent, had read a great deal, and seriously thought over what he read. He loved science but concluded that following a scientific career meant joining the Philistines. He lived simply, earned little through translation work, and devoted himself to social work. He had no ambition to lead men and considered no work too insignificant to do.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the narrator defended Polakóff when speaking to the procureur about the search.
response: The narrator gave his word of honour that Polakóff had never taken part in any political affair. He explained that Polakóff was a promising young zoologist about to pass his final examinations, and that conducting the search would ruin the scientific career of someone who had struggled through great hardships to reach his position. He also mentioned that Polakóff was regarded at the university as one of the future glories of Russian science.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how did the narrator prove that the procureur was being deceptive about the note and envelope found at Polakóff's?
response: The narrator noticed that the envelope was addressed in black chalk while the note was written in common lead pencil. He pointed out that a practical man like the procureur would have noticed the two were written in different pencils, proving they did not belong together. He accused the procureur of putting the letter in the envelope himself and stated the letter was not actually written to Polakóff.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what happened to Polakóff after his arrest and how the narrator later confirmed his expectations about Polakóff's behavior.
response: Polakóff was kept under arrest for several weeks and then released due to intervention from his scientific friends. When the narrator met Polakóff in 1878 at Geneva, Polakóff confirmed he had denied any knowledge of the letter or the person represented by V. E. The narrator noted this was exactly what he expected, as Polakóff would have preferred being marched to Siberia rather than involve another person.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the circumstances that led to the despair and death of the person exiled in Siberia.
response: The exiled man was a scrupulously laborious and imaginative scientific mind, but being in a small Siberian town far from libraries, he could only incorporate research done up to his exile date. He knew important work had been done since but couldn't access necessary books. He had no hope even as his liberation approached, knowing he would be exiled again to some hamlet in Eastern Russia rather than allowed in university towns. This despair, which he compared to Faust's, eventually led him to end his life on a gloomy night after sending his wife and children to Russia.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the state of the socialist movement in England in 1886 and how did different social classes respond to it?
response: In 1886, the socialist movement in England was in full swing, with large bodies of workers and middle-class young people joining in principal towns. An acute industrial crisis caused workers to beg for bread and sleep in Trafalgar Square. After riots in Piccadilly, the middle classes subscribed money for relief in the East End and leaders received only light sentences of two to three months. Interest in socialism was great across all social layers. In workers' homes, discussions were held with hope, while in wealthy mansions there was apprehension, but both showed earnestness. The wealthy mainly wanted to know what socialists wanted and what concessions were necessary to avoid conflicts.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the wealthy believed about the possibility of revolution in England and the workers' demands.
response: The wealthy held a firm conviction that revolution was impossible in England. They believed the claims of most workers had not yet reached the precision or extent of socialist claims, and that workers would be satisfied with much less. They thought secondary concessions offering a slight increase in well-being or leisure would be accepted by working classes as a pledge of more to come in the future. As one sentiment expressed it, 'We are a left-centre country, we live by compromises.'

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain how Kropotkin characterizes the modern ideal of a workman under the division of labour system.
response: Kropotkin characterizes the modern ideal of a workman as a person—man, woman, or even child—without knowledge of any handicraft or conception of the industry they work in. They are only capable of making the same infinitesimal part of something all day long for their whole life, such as pushing a coal cart at a given spot or making the spring of a penknife. They become mere servants to machines, flesh-and-bone parts of immense machinery, with no idea how or why the machinery performs its movements.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what economists proclaimed about the division of labour among nations.
response: Economists proclaimed the necessity of dividing all humanity into national workshops, each with its own speciality. They taught that certain countries were predestined by nature for specific roles: Hungary and Russia to grow corn to feed manufacturing countries, Britain to provide cottons, iron goods, and coal to the world market, and Belgium to produce woollen cloth. Even within each nation, each region was supposed to have its own speciality.

instruction: According to the passage only, what criticism does Kropotkin make about the narrow conception of life based on profits?
response: Kropotkin criticizes the narrow conception that profits are the only leading motive of human society, along with the stubborn view that what existed yesterday would last forever. He argues this proved to be in disaccordance with the tendencies of human life, and that life took another direction. He also notes that as work becomes simpler, more monotonous and wearisome, the individual's requirements for varying work and exercising all capacities become more prominent.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author describe as the present tendency of civilized nations?
response: The author affirms that the present tendency of civilized nations is for each nation to be her own agriculturist and manufacturer, each individual working in the field and in some industrial art, and each individual combining scientific knowledge with the knowledge of a handicraft.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what factors created the impression that West European nations were destined to become the manufacturers of the world.
response: The prodigious growth of industries in Great Britain, the simultaneous development of international traffic permitting transport of raw materials and food on a gigantic scale, the steadily increasing speed of trans-oceanic communications, and the steadily increasing facilities of shipping all contributed to creating this impression.

instruction: According to the passage only, what were the economic results of Britain's industrial development from 1810 to 1878?
response: During this period, coal output grew from 10 to 133,000,000 tons, imports of raw materials rose from 30 to 380,000,000 tons, exports of manufactured goods increased from 46 to 200,000,000 pounds, the commercial fleet tonnage nearly trebled, and fifteen thousand miles of railways were built. Wealth accumulated rapidly in the hands of privileged classes, and taxed property doubled during the last thirty years of this period.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe Japan's growth in textile manufacturing between 1887 and 1909.
response: Japan's textile industry grew dramatically during this period. The total production of tissues rose from £1,200,000 in 1887 to £14,270,000 in 1895 and then to £22,500,000 in 1909. By 1909, Japan had 3,756 textile factories with 1,785,700 spindles, 51,185 power-looms, and 783,155 hand-looms. Cottons made up nearly two-fifths of the total tissue production. This growth made Japan a serious competitor to great industrial nations in Eastern Asian markets within about twenty-five years.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how did the United States' manufacturing sector develop between 1870 and 1905?
response: Between 1870 and 1890, the number of persons employed in American manufactures more than doubled, and the value of their produce nearly trebled. In the next fifteen years, employment increased by nearly fifty percent while production value nearly doubled again. By 1905, the yearly production of textiles reached 2,147,441,400 dollars, which was twice as large as the United Kingdom's yearly production in the same branch. The US also began exporting iron in 1890 using admirable new metallurgical methods, and its pig-iron and steel output exceeded Britain's.

instruction: According to the passage only, what was identified as the main cause of the 1886-1887 crisis affecting manufacturing countries?
response: The passage states that all examinations of the crisis unanimously agreed with the Parliamentary Commission's conclusion that manufacturing countries could not find customers that would enable them to realize high profits. Since profits are the basis of capitalist industry, low profits explained all the subsequent consequences, including reduced wages, fewer workers, reduced days of employment, and manufacture of lower quality goods.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author argue about the possibility of Western European nations growing their own food?
response: The author argues that plenty of food could be grown on the territories of Western Europe for much more than their present populations. He considers the teaching that these territories are too overcrowded to grow sufficient food to be totally erroneous.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the author means when he says knowledge and invention have become 'international growths.'
response: The author means that knowledge, invention, boldness of thought, enterprise, and improvements in social organization can no longer be kept within political boundaries. They cross seas and mountains, and if a discovery is announced in one country, the same problem will likely be solved by inventors of different nationalities within weeks, as if there were a common atmosphere favoring the germination of ideas.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author say about the idea of maintaining industrial supremacy through force or technical superiority?
response: The author acknowledges that some will argue pioneers must maintain supremacy through superior technical knowledge or force if necessary. However, he counters that force is reciprocal and that the strongest battalions are those fighting for new rights against outgrown privileges. He also notes that knowledge cannot be cultivated for home use only, making monopolizing technical genius outdated thinking.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why Britain imported more cereals in 1887 compared to 1860.
response: Britain imported cereals for 17,000,000 inhabitants in 1887 instead of 10,000,000 in 1860 primarily because more than 2,000,000 acres had gone out of cultivation. The area under wheat was reduced by 1,590,000 acres, and the area under barley, oats, beans, and other spring crops was reduced by a further 560,000 acres. This was due to agriculture falling into neglect, not simply population growth or increased consumption.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the common argument used to explain the change in British agriculture, and how does the passage refute it?
response: The common argument was that the character of agriculture had changed from growing wheat to producing meat and milk. However, the passage refutes this by showing that the area under green crops like potatoes and turnips also decreased (by 280,000 and 180,000 acres respectively), and while permanent pasture increased by 2,800,000 acres, there was no corresponding increase in live stock sufficient to cover even the area reclaimed from waste land.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the trend in British agricultural land use between 1885 and 1895.
response: Between 1885 and 1895, the area under all corn crops in Great Britain decreased from 8,392,006 acres to 7,400,227 acres. The area under wheat dropped dramatically from 2,478,318 acres to 1,417,641 acres. The area under green crops was also reduced by nearly 500,000 acres (from 3,521,602 to 3,225,762 acres). This represented a total loss of nearly 1,000,000 acres in cereals over ten years.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what new agricultural method involving microbes is described, and what is its purpose?
response: The passage describes a method of watering soil with special liquids containing specific microbes. These beneficent microbes are 'sown' into the soil where they rapidly develop and fertilize it. This method was being experimented with on a large scale in Germany to transform peat-bogs and heavy soils into rich meadows and fields.

instruction: Using only the passage, what kinds of falsifications were discovered by public laboratories in France and Belgium regarding seeds and manure?
response: The laboratories discovered that manures often contained only one-fifth of the nutritious elements they were supposed to contain, and some manures from 'respectable' firms contained injurious matters with no nutritious parts at all. For seeds, samples of grass seeds were found containing 20 percent injurious grasses, 20 percent colored sand grains to deceive buyers, or even 10 percent of a deadly poisonous grass.

instruction: According to the passage only, what example is given about butter prices comparing Bavaria and London in 1890?
response: A friend of the author got butter from Bavaria by parcel post for less than 11 shillings for eleven pounds (including 10s. for the butter, 2s. 2d. for parcel post, 6d. for money order, and 2½d. for the letter). Meanwhile, butter of inferior quality with 10 to 15 percent water was being sold in London at 1s. 6d. per pound at the same time.

instruction: Using only the passage, what did L. de Lavergne point out about the United States regarding guano approximately fifty years before the passage was written?
response: L. de Lavergne pointed out that the States were the chief importers of guano at that time. In 1854, they imported guano almost to the same amount as Britain, and they also had sixty-two manufactories of guano which supplied it to the amount of sixteen times the imports.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how many samples of seeds were sent to farmers annually according to the Experimental Farms' Reports for 1909, and what was the purpose?
response: On average, 38,000 samples of seeds were sent to farmers every year. In 1909, more than 38,000 farmers united in experiments to determine the relative merits of different sorts of wheat, oats, and barley under trial.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did Dr. William Saunders believe about the system of supplying farmers with small quantities of choice seeds?
response: Dr. William Saunders believed that this system of supplying a great number of farmers with small quantities of choice seeds contributed notably to increase the yield of corn in Canada.

instruction: Using only the passage, what is the average potato yield per acre in Jersey compared to the country average?
response: The average potato crop in the country is six tons per acre, while in Jersey it is nearly twice as big.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the results of Professor Aimé Girard's potato growing experiments in France.
response: Professor Girard studied the best conditions for growing potatoes including variety, depth of tilling and planting, and distance between plants. He corresponded with about 350 growers and advised them. Those following his instructions obtained crops of twenty to thirty-six tons per acre instead of the usual three tons. Among 90 growers experimenting on fields over one-quarter acre, and 20 on larger areas of three to twenty-eight acres, none obtained less than twelve tons per acre, some got twenty tons, and the average for 110 growers was fourteen and a half tons per acre.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how irrigation improved agricultural productivity in France.
response: On irrigated fields in the Vosges, Vaucluse and other areas of France, six tons of dry hay per acre became the rule even on ungrateful soil, compared to one and a half to two tons in England. Between 1862-1882, 1,355,000 acres of meadows were irrigated, adding the annual meat-food of at least 1,500,000 full-grown persons to the country's yearly income. In the valley of the Seine, land value was doubled by irrigation.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain the two different processes involved in Hallett's experiments with cereals.
response: Hallett's experiments involved two processes: first, a process of selection to create new varieties of cereals (similar to breeding new varieties of cattle); and second, a method of increasing the crop yield by planting each seed separately and wide apart, allowing full development of the young plant which would otherwise be suffocated by neighbors in typical corn-fields.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the French method for selecting wheat seeds that was applied at the Capelle experimental station.
response: French farmers go through wheat fields before harvest, choose the soundest plants bearing two or three equally strong stems with long, well-stocked ears, and take these ears. They then use scissors to crop off the top and bottom of each ear, keeping only the middle part which contains the biggest seeds. With a dozen quarts of such selected grains, they obtain superior quality seeds the following year.

instruction: According to the passage only, what crop yields did M. Dessprèz achieve when planting seeds eight inches apart, and how did this compare to typical results?
response: Dessprèz achieved crops corresponding to 83.8 bushels per acre for the first series and 90.4 bushels for the second series. Even small grains yielded 70.2 and 62 bushels respectively. The crop was more than doubled through seed selection and planting separately eight inches apart, averaging 600 grains obtained from each grain sown.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the agricultural development around Roscoff in Brittany.
response: Around Roscoff, a territory twenty-six miles in diameter is entirely given to market-gardening cultures, with rents exceeding £5 per acre. Nearly 300 steamers call at Roscoff to ship potatoes, onions and other vegetables to London and various English ports as far north as Newcastle. Additionally, 4,000 tons of vegetables are sent yearly to Paris. Small stone walls are erected everywhere with rushes grown on top to provide protection and heat to vegetables, improving both climate and soil.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what crops and agricultural practices are described in the Cherbourg area?
response: In the Cherbourg area, the best vegetables are grown on over 800 acres of land conquered from the sea, dedicated to potatoes exported to London. Another 500 acres grow cauliflower and 125 acres grow Brussels sprouts. Potatoes grown under glass are sent to London from mid-April. Total vegetable export from Cherbourg to England reaches 300,000 cwts., with another 100,000 cwts. from Barfleur. In nearby Surtainville, £2,800 is made from 180 acres with three crops yearly: cabbage in February, early potatoes next, and various autumn crops plus catch crops.

instruction: Using only the passage, what statistics are provided about market-gardening around Paris?
response: Around Paris, no less than 50,000 acres are given to field culture of vegetables and 25,000 acres to forced culture. Sixty years ago, yearly rent paid by market-gardeners already reached £18 to £24 per acre and has increased since. Gross receipts were valued at £240 per acre for larger market-gardeners and twice as much for smaller ones growing early vegetables in frames. At Montreuil, 750 acres belonging to 400 gardeners are covered with stone walls totaling 400 miles in length for growing peach trees, pear trees and vines.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the construction of the cool greenhouses on the Grande Maison estate in Guernsey.
response: The cool greenhouses on the Grande Maison estate are built by a company and rented to gardeners. They are simply made of thin deal board and glass, using the "lean to" or "one roof" system. The back wall is ten feet high, and both the back and two side walls are made of simple grooved boards standing upright. The whole structure is supported by uprights inserted into concrete pillars. They cost not more than 5d. per square foot of glass-covered ground.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what is a typical crop rotation schedule used by Guernsey and Jersey growers in their greenhouses?
response: Growers typically have three crops per year. One example: they start potatoes in December in an unheated house (fires only for sharp frost), harvest in April or May, then plant tomatoes ready by end of summer, with catch crops of peas, radishes, and lettuce in between. Another method: start melons in November, ready in April, followed by tomatoes (in pots or trained as vines) until October, then beans ready for Christmas.

instruction: Using only the passage, what were the estimated export values from Guernsey for various products?
response: The estimated exports from Guernsey were: grapes at 502 tons worth £37,500 (average 9d. per pound), tomatoes at 1,000 tons worth about £30,000, early potatoes (chiefly from fields) at £20,000, radishes and broccoli at £9,250, cut flowers at £3,000, and mushrooms at £200, totaling £99,950.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the state of watch-making in Besançon as observed in 1878 and reported in 1901.
response: In 1878, Besançon was a great centre for watch-making. According to M. Dumazet in 1901, nothing had changed in the habits of the working-class - watch-makers continued to work in their houses or in small workshops. However, there was no complete fabrication of watches; many important parts like wheels were imported from Switzerland or different towns of France, and numerous small secondary workshops grew up nearby for making watch-cases, hands, and other components.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain what happened to the weaving industry in Vienne, south of Lyons.
response: In Vienne, hand-weaving disappeared as 'shoddy' became the leading product. Only 28 concerns remained out of 120 fabriques that existed thirty years prior. Old woollen rags, carpet rags, and dust from carding and spinning were transformed into cloth for ready-made clothing factories - 20,000 yards of shoddy daily. By 1890, only 1,300 hand-looms were working out of 4,000 in 1870. Large factories employing 1,800 workers replaced hand-weavers, while the suburbs developed prosperous gardening and fruit culture.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the industrial region centered on Lyons and what characterizes it.
response: The Lyons industrial region includes the departments of Rhône, Loire, Drôme, Saône-et-Loire, Ain, the southern Jura department, and western Savoy as far as Annecy, with silkworm rearing extending to the Alps, Cévennes Mountains, and Mâcon neighbourhoods. It contains fertile plains and hilly tracks covered with snow in winter, leading rural populations to combine agriculture with industrial occupations like silk-weaving. The région lyonnaise is characterized as a separate centre of French civilisation and art, with a remarkable spirit of research, discovery and invention in scientific and industrial directions.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what conclusion does the author draw about the claims of 'concentration' made by certain economists?
response: The author concludes that the large deductions about 'concentration' made by certain economists are mere hypotheses that are useful for stimulating research, but become noxious when represented as economical laws, since they are not confirmed by carefully observed facts.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the distribution of textile factories by size according to the computed curve mentioned.
response: The distribution is as follows: factories with not less than 500 operatives: 200 factories with 203,100 operatives; 499 to 200 operatives: 660 factories with 231,000 operatives; 199 to 100 operatives: 2,955 factories with 443,120 operatives; 99 to 50 operatives: 1,380 factories with 103,500 operatives; less than 50 operatives: 1,410 factories with 42,300 operatives. Total: 6,605 factories with 1,022,020 operatives.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did Mr. Whitelegge indicate about the workshops not included in his reports in 1900?
response: Mr. Whitelegge wrote that the workshops which did not enter into his reports represented about one-half of all the workshops.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what reasons does the author give for why industries should be scattered across the world rather than concentrated in certain locations?
response: The author argues that current industrial concentrations are based on historical causes like religious wars and national rivalries, plus considerations about sales and export facilities that are becoming less important with improved transport. The author sees no rational reason for anomalies like London being a jam-making center or Paris refining sugar for all of France. Industries should scatter because when producers make goods for themselves rather than distant customers, geographic concentration loses its purpose.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the author identifies as the most important factor in the geographical distribution of industries.
response: The author identifies the intellectual factor as counting for more than all others in determining industrial distribution. This includes the spirit of invention, the capacity of adaptation, and political liberty. The author supports this by noting that Switzerland became a great exporter of steam-engines and railway engines despite having no iron ore, coal, or seaport, demonstrating that local resources and advantageous sea positions are not the dominant factors.

instruction: According to the passage only, why does the author argue that agriculture requires industrial surroundings?
response: The author argues that agriculture cannot develop without machinery, and perfect machinery cannot be used without industrial surroundings and mechanical workshops accessible to farmers. Without nearby workshops, if a thrashing-machine breaks a cog, work stops for a week or more while someone travels to another province for repairs. The author cites seeing this problem in Central Russia and reading about it in an English autobiography from the early nineteenth century.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain how the relationship between scientists and manual work has changed over time.
response: In olden times, men of science did not despise manual work. Galileo made telescopes with his own hands, Newton learned tool management and ground his own lenses, Leibnitz invented machines, and Linnaeus learned botany helping his gardener father. However, under the pretext of division of labour, brain workers have been sharply separated from manual workers. Now most scientists despise manual labour, cannot make or even design scientific instruments, and have raised contempt for manual work to a theory where scientists discover laws, engineers apply them, and workers merely execute patterns without understanding.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what opportunities workers of the past had that modern workers lack.
response: Workers of old had their intelligences stimulated by the variety of work performed in unspecialised workshops, and some enjoyed familiar intercourse with men of science (like Watt and Rennie with Professor Robinson, or Brindley the road-maker with educated men). A well-to-do family's son could work at a wheelwright's shop and become a Smeaton or Stephenson. Modern workers have been deprived of even the small workshop education, with boys and girls driven into mines or factories from age thirteen where they forget what little they learned at school.

instruction: According to the passage only, what is the substance of complaints about the current division of labor in industry?
response: The substance of complaints is that workers whose tasks have been specialised by permanent division of labour have lost intellectual interest in their work and lost their inventive powers. Formerly, manual workers (not scientists or trained engineers) invented or perfected prime motors and machinery that revolutionised industry. But since the great factory system, workers depressed by monotony of work invent no more, as they merely supervise machines without knowing about their complicated movements or how they developed.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why factory workers stopped inventing according to the text.
response: Factory workers stopped inventing because they became depressed by the monotony of their work. A weaver supervising four looms knows nothing about their complicated movements or how the machines developed. Workers condemned to repetitive tasks like binding thread ends know nothing beyond that simple operation. Additionally, scientific education became necessary for further inventions, but that education is refused to workers.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what the author means by 'éducation intégrale' and what its aims should be.
response: Éducation intégrale means complete education that would eliminate the distinction between brain workers and manual workers. Its aim is that by age eighteen or twenty, each student should have thorough knowledge of science sufficient to be useful workers in science, plus general knowledge of technical training bases and skill in a special trade enabling them to participate in manual production of wealth.

instruction: According to the passage only, what evidence does the author provide that the proposed educational system can actually work?
response: The author cites the Moscow Technical School, where the experiment was conducted for twenty consecutive years with many hundreds of boys. According to testimonies of competent judges at exhibitions in Brussels, Philadelphia, Vienna, and Paris, the experiment was a success. The school admitted boys not older than fifteen, requiring substantial knowledge of geometry, algebra, and their mother tongue.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what proportion of a workman's family yearly earnings must be spent on food according to the researches mentioned?
response: According to the researches of Engel (at Berlin) and his followers, the workman's family has to spend one full half of its yearly earnings—that is, six months of labour or often more—to provide its food.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what the author envisions as an alternative to the large industrial factories for workers.
response: The author envisions countless smaller, airy and hygienic workshops and factories at the gates of fields and gardens, where human life is valued more than machinery and extra profits. In these places, men, women and children would not be driven by hunger but attracted by the desire to find activity suited to their tastes, aided by motors and machines to choose work matching their inclinations.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author say about the potential for growing food under rational conditions?
response: The author states that if you make yourselves the soil and partly control the temperature and moisture each crop requires, growing the yearly food of a family under rational conditions of culture requires so little labour that it might almost be done as a mere change from other pursuits.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the flower-growing industry developed in the Scilly Islands.
response: When shipping and piloting declined, Scillonians first turned to growing potatoes, which was profitable for many years with about 1,000 tons exported annually. When potato exports declined to less than half, they tried fishing, then began growing flowers. Since frost and snow are practically unknown there, they started with wild narcissuses, then added daffodils (a hundred varieties) and lilies, especially arum-lilies for church decoration. Flowers are grown in narrow strips sheltered by dwarf hedges, with movable glass-houses used to create succession of crops from after Christmas until April or May.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what are the crop yields from irrigated meadows near Milan compared to unirrigated lands?
response: On Milan's irrigated meadows with constant water flow, six crops per year are obtained, yielding 80-100 tons of grass (20-25 tons dry hay) per hectare, or 8-10 tons per acre. Lower meadows yield 13 tons of dry hay per acre. For Indian corn, irrigated lands in Italy produce 78-89 bushels per acre, compared to 56-67 bushels on unirrigated Italian lands and only 28-33 bushels in France.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain Sir A. Cotton's wheat planting method and results.
response: Sir A. Cotton advocated deep cultivation and planting wheat seeds wide apart. For his best wheat variety, he obtained an average of 55 ears per plant with 3 oz. of grain of fair quality (about 63 lbs. per bushel), corresponding to 90 bushels per acre. His results were similar to those obtained at Tomblaine and Capelle agricultural stations. However, the passage notes his experiments were not reported in a thoroughly scientific way, and the possibility of profitably increasing wheat crops by his methods still needs to be tested scientifically.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the potential of replanted wheat as described by M. Toubeau and supported by Prof. Grandeau.
response: M. Toubeau suggested that replanted wheat could be a powerful means of increasing crops in Western Europe. Though not yet practically tested, Prof. Grandeau believed the method must have a great future. With plants yielding up to 1,000 grains each, the yearly wheat-food for one person (about 265 lbs.) could theoretically be grown on 250 square yards, with replanting requiring only ten to twelve hours' work for an experienced hand.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the growth of market-gardening in Great Britain between 1875 and 1894 and how it compared to other countries.
response: In Great Britain, the area under market-gardens increased from 38,957 acres in 1875 to 88,210 acres in 1894. However, this increase was described as a trifle compared to similar increases in France, Belgium, and the United States. In France, the area given to market-gardening was estimated at 1,075,000 acres in 1892—four times more in proportion to cultivable area than in Britain.

instruction: Using only the passage, what examples are given of common vegetables imported to the United Kingdom that could be grown domestically?
response: The passage mentions several common vegetables imported that could be grown in the UK: lettuces (from France and the Azores), early cucumbers (from Holland), beetroot and pickling cabbage (from Holland and Brittany), and onions (from Belgium, Germany, Holland, and France). It also notes that late potatoes were imported from Holland, Germany, and Belgium, and early potatoes from the Channel Islands could potentially be grown in South Devon.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the fruit and vegetable cultivation statistics for Belgium mentioned in the census data.
response: According to the Annuaire statistique de la belgique, out of 6,443,500 acres of cultivated area, Belgium dedicated the following to fruit and vegetable growing: orchards 117,600 acres, market-gardens 103,460 acres, vineries 173 acres (which increased since), growing of trees for afforestation/gardens/orchards 7,475 acres, and potatoes 456,000 acres. As a result, Belgium exports about £250,000 worth more vegetables and nearly £500,000 worth more fruit than it imports annually.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain the glass-frame cultivation methods used in Holland's Westland region.
response: In the Westland region between Rotterdam and the sea, gardeners use transportable glass-frames that can be moved at will to cover plants for several days or weeks. They cultivate cucumbers, melons, radishes, carrots, lettuce, and strawberries under glass, largely without heating. The different produce comes one after another. Gardeners apply the latest scientific progress rather than routine methods and have acquired great skill in handling glass-frames with facility, rarely breaking glass. The region also has countless glass-houses for grapes, peaches, cherries, beans, and tomatoes, with or without heating.

instruction: Using only the passage, summarize how dessert grape prices at Covent Garden fluctuated during 1907-1908.
response: In early January, Belgian Colmar grapes sold at 6d. to 10d. per pound. Prices rose through January and February, reaching 1s. 6d. to 2s. 6d. by mid-March and April due to late Hamburg grapes. English grapes from Worthing were preferred and sold at 2s. to 4s. per pound in late April/early May 1907. When Belgian Hamburg grapes arrived late May, prices fell to 10d. to 1s. 4d., dropping further to 5d.-7d. in June-July. From September-November 1908, best Guernsey grapes were quoted at 6d. (some at 4d.). Prices rose to 10d.-1s. 1d. in early November but fell again to 6d.-9d. around Christmas when new Belgian Colmars arrived.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why sociability is considered the greatest advantage in the struggle for life.
response: Sociability enables even the feeblest insects, birds, and mammals to resist or protect themselves from predators. It permits longevity, allows species to rear progeny with minimal energy waste while maintaining population numbers despite slow birth-rates, and enables migration to new habitats. Species that abandon sociability are doomed to decay, while those that combine best have the greatest chances of survival and further evolution.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how a sense of justice develops in gregarious animals and provide an example given.
response: A collective sense of justice grows to become a habit among social animals because society would be impossible if individuals constantly abused personal advantages without others interfering for the wronged. For example, if a lazy sparrow tries to appropriate another's nest or steals straw from it, the group interferes against the lazy comrade. Without such interference being the rule, nesting associations of birds could not exist.

instruction: According to the passage only, what evidence is provided for compassion among wild animals?
response: The passage cites several examples: a weasel that picked up and carried away an injured comrade, Captain Stansbury's observation of a blind pelican being fed by other pelicans with fish brought from thirty miles away, and H.A. Weddell's observation of strong male vicunas covering the retreat of their herd and lagging behind to protect others when pursued by hunters.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what did H.A. Weddell observe about animal behavior during his journey to Bolivia and Peru?
response: Weddell observed strong males covering the retreat of the herd and lagging behind in order to protect the retreat. The passage also notes that facts of compassion with wounded comrades are continually mentioned by field zoologists.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the two different aspects of the 'struggle for life' that are discussed.
response: The passage describes two aspects: the direct struggle for food and safety among separate individuals, and what Darwin called the 'metaphorical' struggle, which is very often collective and directed against adverse circumstances.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does Wallace suggest about competition between closely-allied species that differs from the idea of actual warfare between them?
response: Wallace suggests that competition may not involve actual war where the stronger kills the weaker. The weaker species physically may prevail through more rapid multiplication, better withstanding climate vicissitudes, or greater cunning in escaping common enemies. In such cases, one species succumbs not because it is exterminated or starved out, but because it does not accommodate itself well to new conditions that the other species does.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what did ethnology conclude about the primitive form of organization of mankind?
response: Ethnology concluded that societies, bands, or tribes—not families—were the primitive form of organization of mankind and its earliest ancestors. The family is described as a very late product of human evolution, not a primitive form of organization.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain Darwin's view on which type of ape species man likely descended from and why.
response: Darwin was inclined to consider man as descended from some comparatively weak but social species, like the chimpanzee, rather than from some stronger but unsociable species, like the gorilla. This was because he understood that isolately-living apes never could have developed into man-like beings.

instruction: According to the passage only, what evidence from the stone age supports the idea that early humans lived in societies?
response: Evidence includes: isolated finds of stone implements are very rare while large quantities are typically found together; cave-dwellings in places like the Dordogne valleys are superposed in storeys resembling nesting colonies; flint implements in caves are numberless; inhabitants of the Aurignac region partook of tribal meals at burials; and neolithic stations show numerous traces of rather dense populations with whole workshops of flint implements indicating many workers came together.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why savages practice infanticide according to the author.
response: According to the passage, ignorance rather than cruelty maintains infanticide. Savages cannot rear all their children despite taking measures to limit birth rates. They practice infanticide reluctantly and abandon it as soon as they can increase their regular means of subsistence. Parents obey this obligation unwillingly and resort to compromises to save newborns when they can afford to.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the author compares the abandonment of old people among savages to other situations.
response: The author compares it to a wounded soldier's situation. When a soldier cannot move and knows he will die if left behind, he asks his best friend to discharge a gun into his dying body before the detachment advances. Similarly, old savages who feel they are a burden ask to die themselves, insisting on this duty to the community. The author also notes that Arctic expeditions have done the same when they could no longer carry invalid comrades.

instruction: According to the passage only, what example does the author give of a missionary who effectively stopped infanticide?
response: The author cites Veniaminoff as an example. Rather than moralizing savages with sermons, he crossed the sea of Okhotsk every year in a miserable boat or traveled on dogs among the Tchuktchis, supplying them with bread and fishing implements. Through this practical assistance, he really stopped infanticide.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why medieval architecture achieved such grandeur according to the author.
response: Medieval architecture achieved grandeur because it originated from an eminently social life and was born out of a grand idea of brotherhood and unity fostered by the city. It was a natural development of handicraft where builders knew through personal experience what artistic effects could be obtained from materials. Each monument resulted from collective experience accumulated in each craft, and the whole city contributed to it. The vigour of city life permeated the buildings, which symbolized the grandeur of an organism where every mason and stone-cutter was a builder.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how medieval cathedrals were funded and built by the community.
response: Medieval cathedrals were built with relatively small monetary means - Cologne Cathedral began with only 500 marks yearly, and even at completion rarely exceeded 14,000 marks annually. Basel Cathedral was built with equally small means. However, each corporation contributed its part of stone, work, and decorative genius. Each guild expressed its political conceptions in stone or bronze, told the city's history, and bestowed love upon the monument through stained windows, paintings, decorated gates, and stone decorations of every corner.

instruction: Using only the passage, what inventions and developments does the author attribute to the medieval period?
response: The passage attributes to the medieval period: parchment and paper, printing and engraving, improved glass and steel, gunpowder, clocks, telescopes, the mariner's compass, the reformed calendar, decimal notation, algebra, trigonometry, chemistry, and counterpoint (described as equivalent to a new creation of music). The author also notes medieval science prepared the discovery of new principles in mechanical sciences and accustomed explorers to observe facts and reason from them as inductive science.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the passage identifies as the substance of all Socialism.
response: The substance of all Socialism, according to the passage, is that the few prevent the masses from producing what they need for subsistence, forcing them instead to produce whatever offers the greatest profits to monopolists. The few receive the lion's share while reducing the masses to having no means of subsistence for even a week in advance.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how the passage characterizes the creation of modern civilization and infrastructure.
response: The passage characterizes modern civilization as the product of thousands of years of labor by millions of people across generations. Forests were cleared, marshes drained, soil cultivated, highways and railroads built, rivers made navigable, harbors constructed, and mines dug. Whole generations lived and died in misery, oppressed and worn out by toil, to hand down this immense inheritance. Every acre of soil has been watered by the sweat of several races, and every mile of railway has received its share of human blood.

instruction: According to the passage only, why does the passage argue that no thought or invention can be considered individual property?
response: The passage argues that every thought and invention is common property because it is born of both the past and present. Thousands of known and unknown inventors who died in poverty cooperated in creating machines. Writers, poets, and scholars labored to increase knowledge and create the atmosphere of scientific thought needed for modern marvels. These thinkers were themselves supported by the labor of past centuries and upheld by legions of workers and craftsmen.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the shoemaker becomes wealthy according to the author's example.
response: The shoemaker becomes wealthy not through mere saving, but by exploiting others. After saving some money, he takes on apprentices (children of poor people) who work while learning the trade. He then hires working men who are paid half a crown for work worth five shillings. His workers and apprentices bring him nearly one pound a day beyond his own labor. This allows him to enlarge his business and gradually become rich.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how does the author argue that modern commerce involves exploitation even when a merchant appears to exploit nobody?
response: The author argues that while the merchant himself may just sit at his desk, telegraph orders, and freight ships, his profit depends on exploiting needy workers. He finds men willing to cross seas and endure hardship for miserable pay, and dock laborers who work for starvation wages, only because these workers are needy and starving. The merchant's wealth thus springs from the poverty of these workers.

instruction: According to the passage only, what is the author's central argument about the origin of fortunes?
response: The author argues that everywhere you look—whether in commerce, finance, manufacturing, or land—the wealth of the wealthy springs from the poverty of the poor. What is called being economical and having frugal habits is actually grinding the face of the poor through exploitation of their labor.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does Kropotkin argue is the 'supreme aim' after bread has been secured for all?
response: Kropotkin argues that after bread has been secured, leisure is the supreme aim. This leisure would provide the possibility of developing everyone's intellectual capacities and obtaining joys that are currently reserved for only a few.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why Kropotkin believes luxury is currently a crime but will become important after a social revolution.
response: Kropotkin states that luxury is currently a crime because hundreds of thousands of people lack bread, coal, clothing, and shelter - satisfying luxury means the worker's child must go without bread. However, in a society where all have necessary food and shelter, what we now consider luxuries will be more keenly felt as legitimate needs.

instruction: According to the passage only, what criticism does Kropotkin address regarding communist societies and how did American desert communities fail?
response: Kropotkin addresses the criticism that communist societies only focus on material life and won't provide beautiful pictures, optical instruments, luxurious furniture, or artistic jewelry - only bread, meat, and drab linen. The American desert communities failed because they believed providing basic cloth and occasional music was enough, forgetting that artistic feeling exists in agriculturists too. When individual tastes emerged, quarrels arose over buying pianos or scientific instruments, and the societies could only exist by crushing individual feeling and artistic tendency.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why the anarchist Commune would differ from societies that crushed individual feeling and artistic tendency.
response: The anarchist Commune would differ because it understands that while producing all necessary material goods, it must also strive to satisfy all manifestations of the human mind. Anarchy's strength lies in understanding all human faculties and passions, ignoring none, rather than crushing individual feeling, artistic tendency, and development as other societies did.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how a person would divide their daily work time in the envisioned anarchist society.
response: A person would work 4 or 5 hours of manual labor as their contribution to general production for society's necessities. They would then have 5 or 6 additional hours to employ according to their tastes, satisfying artistic, scientific, or hobby needs by associating with others in voluntary societies.

instruction: According to the passage only, how would the relationship between authors and printers change in the future society described?
response: Authors would no longer rely on exploited workers to print their books while remaining ignorant of printing conditions. Instead, when workers are educated and have their own ideas to share, authors and scientific men would combine with printers to produce their work together. Authors would learn to handle composing-sticks and type themselves, and admirers would gather to set type and operate presses, finding enjoyment in the process.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what do Socialists maintain about work in a society freed from capitalist rule, and how is this claim typically received?
response: Socialists maintain that such a society would make work agreeable and would suppress all repugnant and unhealthy drudgery. However, when they make these claims, they are laughed at.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the advanced factory in the Midland counties and explain why it was organized so well.
response: The factory occupies fifty English acres of land with fifteen acres roofed with glass. It has fire-proof brick pavement kept as clean as a miner's cottage, and the glass roof is carefully cleaned by dedicated workers. Despite forging steel ingots weighing up to twenty tons in furnaces over a thousand degrees, the heat is barely noticeable when doors are closed. Machines operate quietly using hydraulic pressure rather than noisy stampers. The engineer explained that this excellent organization was simply a question of economy—machines last longer when properly adjusted, utilizing heat saves coal, and workers perform better with good lighting, cleanliness, and adequate space.

instruction: According to the passage only, what evidence does the author provide about the mine of the future already existing, and what were its production statistics?
response: The author states he personally visited such a mine in England. Despite its immense depth of 466 yards, it produced a thousand tons of coal daily with only two hundred miners—five tons per worker per day. This compared favorably to the average of the two thousand pits in England at the time, which was hardly three hundred tons per year per man.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the average coal production per man per year in English pits during the early 1890s, and how did this compare to the mine the author visited?
response: The average for the two thousand pits in England was hardly three hundred tons a year per man. In contrast, the mine the author visited had only two hundred miners producing five tons a day per worker, which was significantly more productive.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author argues that phalansteries would not be suitable as a general living arrangement for society.
response: The author argues that while phalansteries (essentially immense hotels) may please some people at certain periods of their life, the great mass of people prefers family life and isolated apartments. Human nature normally desires isolation alternating with time spent in society. A phalanstery would be hateful as a general rule because it fails to account for people's need for rest and intimacy during leisure hours.

instruction: According to the passage only, what solution does the author suggest for reducing domestic work, and what example is given?
response: The author suggests that machinery can undertake three-quarters of household cares. As an example, the author mentions that while boot-blacking by hand is ridiculous and stupid work, hairdressers already have machines for brushing hair, and the same principle has been applied to boots—machines for blacking boots are now in general use.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the 'go-canny' theory that caused terror among British employers in 1887?
response: The 'go-canny' theory was a movement where agitators preached 'Bad pay, bad work,' encouraging workers to take it easy, not overwork themselves, and waste all they can. British employers feared this would demoralize workers and kill their industry.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what causes are identified for laziness in children and workers.
response: The passage identifies several causes: children may appear lazy because they are badly taught or don't understand the material, or suffer from cerebral anemia caused by poverty and anti-hygienic education. Workers may be lazy because they are in jobs that don't match their temperament or capacities, they rebel against enriching employers while being stuck in hovels, or they hate their trade because they never properly learned it and cannot improve due to bad work habits already acquired.

instruction: According to the passage only, what argument does the author make about great men and idleness?
response: The author argues that many great men, including Darwin and Stephenson, were considered idlers before finding their right path. They were lazy only until they discovered work that suited them, after which they became laborious to excess.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author suggest a free society should do if it sees the number of idlers increasing?
response: The author suggests that a free society should first look for the cause of laziness in order to suppress it, before having recourse to punishment.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the author's recommended approach to teaching children who lack order or regular habits.
response: The author recommends letting children first inculcate order among themselves, and then using the laboratory, workshop, and work done in a limited space with many tools under an intelligent teacher to teach them method, rather than relying on schools whose only order is the symmetry of benches.

instruction: According to the passage only, what alternative activities does the author suggest for a workman who is stifled by repetitive machine work?
response: The author suggests giving the workman the chance to till the soil, fell trees in the forest, sail the seas in a storm, or dash through space on an engine, rather than forcing him to attend to a small machine, plough the head of a screw, or drill the eye of a needle all his life.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author believes establishing a distinction between qualified and simple work would be harmful to society.
response: The author argues that establishing such a distinction would maintain all the inequalities of present society by fixing a dividing line between workers and those who govern them. It would divide society into two distinct classes - an aristocracy of knowledge above the lower orders - where one class is doomed to serve the other. This would revive a peculiarity of the current crumbling society and give it the sanction of the Social Revolution, essentially setting up an already condemned abuse as a principle.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author claim is the real reason engineers, scientists, and doctors are paid more than laborers?
response: The author claims it is not due to their 'cost of production' but rather due to a monopoly of education or a monopoly of industry. Engineers, scientists, and doctors merely exploit their capital - their diplomas - similar to how middle-class employers exploit a factory or how nobles used to exploit their titles of nobility.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does the author explain why an employer pays an engineer twenty times more than a labourer?
response: The author explains it is simply due to personal interest. If the engineer can economize £4,000 a year on the cost of production, the employer pays him £800. The employer parts with extra money when he expects to gain more by it - this is described as the essence of the Capitalist system.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain Adam Smith's argument in favor of the division of labor and what counterarguments the passage raises against it.
response: Adam Smith argued that dividing labor and specializing increases productivity, using the example of a smith who can make 2,300 nails a day if he only makes nails, versus 200-300 if unspecialized. However, the passage argues Smith ignored that such a worker would lose interest in his work, become entirely dependent on his employer, face unemployment for months, and see his wages fall since he could easily be replaced by an apprentice.

instruction: According to the passage only, what are the consequences of the division of labor on society and workers?
response: The passage states that division of labor divides society into two classes: producers who consume little, only do physical work, don't think, and work badly because their brains are inactive; and consumers who produce little but think for others, yet think badly because they don't know the world of manual laborers. Workers become labeled for life to specific tasks, understanding nothing of machinery, business, or industry as a whole, which destroys their love of work and spirit of invention.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how does the author say socialists responded to the division of labor, and what is the author's view of this response?
response: The passage states that most socialists, even those who criticized economic science, justified maintaining the division of labor. They argued that after the Revolution, workers would still do their specialized tasks (like sharpening pins) but for fewer hours, while others would specialize in machines, literature, science, and art.
