response: The author recommends Ralston's Early Russian History, Songs of the Russian People, Russian Folk Tales, and his translation of Afanásieff's Legends; Rambaud's La Russie épique and his History of Russia; Le roman russe by Vogue; Impressions of Russia by George Brandes (translated by Eastman), and Brandes's Moderne Geister which contains a chapter on Turguéneff.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what makes the Russian Encyclopædia Dictionary of Brockhaus-Efron notable according to the author.
response: The author considers it one of the best encyclopædias in Europe. Though it began as a translation of the Lexikon of Brockhaus, it was taken over by a group of Russian scientists including Mendeléeff, Woiéikoff, and V. Solovióff. It comprises 82 volumes completed in 1904, and notably all articles on chemistry and chemical technics were either written or carefully revised by Mendeléeff.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what role did Mendeléeff play in the creation of encyclopædias in Europe?
response: According to the passage, all articles on chemistry and chemical technics in European encyclopædias have been either written or carefully revised by Mendeléeff.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the editor Marks was able to publish complete editions of Russian writers' works at very low prices.
response: The passage states that the astoundingly low prices can only be explained by a circulation which exceeds 200,000 copies every year, achieved through Marks's weekly illustrated paper.

instruction: According to the passage only, what contribution did the composer Glínka make related to Russian literature?
response: Glínka made a most beautiful opera called Rustán I Ludmíla based on a fairy tale, in which Russian, Finnish, Turkish, and Oriental music are intermingled to characterise the different heroes.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe Maxim Gorky's early life and how he came to be a writer.
response: Gorky was born in 1868 in Nizhni Novgorod on the Volga. His father was a merchant or artisan, and his mother was a remarkable peasant woman who died soon after his birth. Orphaned at nine, he was raised by his father's relatives. His childhood was unhappy, and he eventually ran away to work on a Volga River steamer. Later he wandered on foot with tramps in South Russia, during which time he wrote short stories that were published in a newspaper of Northern Caucasia.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain what made Gorky's writing distinctive and why he became popular so quickly.
response: Gorky's writing combined fine artistic form with a new note of strength and courage. His short stories featured ordinary tramps and slum-dwellers rather than heroes, yet offered fine analysis of complicated human feelings, original characters, and admirably interwove human psychology with natural backgrounds like calm seas or sun-burnt prairies. He found a happy combination of realism with idealism that Russian folk-novelists had been striving for, using an unexpected variety of fine touches—both refined and brutal, tender and harsh—to depict human feelings with greater complexity than typical novelists.

instruction: Using only the passage, identify some of Gorky's short stories mentioned and describe the subject matter of his early works.
response: The passage mentions stories including "Málva," "Tehelkásh," "The Ex-Men," and "Twenty-six Men and One Girl." His early short stories drew their heroes from the tramps of Southern Russia—men who had broken with regular society, never accepted permanent work, labored only as casuals in Black Sea seaports, slept in dosshouses or ravines, and tramped in summer from Odessa to the Crimea and Northern Caucasia.

instruction: Based only on the passage, how does Górky's portrayal of tramps differ from other Russian writers' treatment of downtrodden characters?
response: Unlike other Russian writers who engage in whining and self-castigation, Górky's tramps have a refreshing note of energy and courage. His tramps are miserably poor but "don't care" and don't make a virtue of helplessness as Dostoyévsky's heroes did. Even the most downtrodden among them dreams of reforming the world rather than complaining about their hard lot.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the character Váreñka Olésova and her view of the typical Russian literary hero.
response: Váreñka Olésova is described as a girl full of vitality, a primitive creature untouched by ideals of liberty and equality, but intensely alive, independent, and very much herself. She mocks the typical Russian hero as "always silly and stupid, always sick of something, always thinking about something that cannot be understood." She describes him as miserable, constantly thinking and talking, making declarations of love, then thinking more until he marries, after which he talks nonsense to his wife and abandons her.

instruction: According to the passage only, what is Górky's favorite character type and where does he find examples of this type?
response: Górky's favorite type is the "rebel" - a man in full revolt against society who is also a strong man and a power. He finds at least the embryo of this type among the tramps with whom he has lived, which is why he takes his most interesting heroes from this stratum of society.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what were Professor Huxley's intentions when he introduced Physiography, and what problems was he trying to address?
response: Professor Huxley's intentions were excellent. At the time, natural sciences were almost entirely excluded from schools. Geography teaching was very poor - political geography was merely a collection of names, and physical geography was too abstract, incoherent, wide, and superficial to be useful in education. Through Physiography, natural sciences were essentially smuggled into schools, and Huxley showed how the study of Nature could be approached through examining things close at hand, bringing about a far-reaching reform.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author believes Heimatskunde (Local History) is no longer sufficient for teaching children about the Earth.
response: The author argues that while Heimatskunde might have worked fifty years ago in remote villages, it no longer serves its purpose in the era of railway civilization and world traffic. Children cannot be prevented from gaining general knowledge of the Earth even at early ages - they eat oranges and bananas from other latitudes, see exotic plants at Kew, and learn about distant lands through books and illustrated papers. Children now live by imagination as travelers to Australia, Africa, and distant islands, so their knowledge cannot be limited to studying only their own locality.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author believe is the proper role of studying one's own locality in education?
response: The author believes studying one's own locality has immense importance, but not for learning about Nature altogether. Instead, it should be used as a means for giving more concrete form to acquired knowledge and for acquiring knowledge through personal work and observation. For example, children should learn to trace angles on the ground and make maps of ponds or brooks using compass and paces - not to become geographers, but to understand concretely what maps mean and to better comprehend geometry, mathematics, and physics.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why classical education was originally considered valuable and why the author believes its role has changed.
response: Classical education was originally valuable because it represented a return to Nature and scientific methods, opposing monastic scholasticism. Studying antiquity meant returning to natural science, natural art, and municipal freedom. However, the author argues the parts are now reversed - science can no longer be studied in Aristotle but must be studied in Newton and Mayer. Those who neglect Newton for Aristotle now stand for "Words against Science," similar to how opponents of classical education stood five hundred years ago.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the author views the relationship between natural sciences and human education.
response: The author acknowledges the criticism that natural sciences do not give education the human character it ought to have, but argues this can be changed. The ancient Greeks did not separate Man from Nature, and the divorce between human sciences and natural sciences was accomplished artificially, especially by schools that kept students of Man ignorant of Nature and vice versa. The author sees this separation ending as we return to the Greek spirit that conceived Man as part of the Cosmos, evidenced by the revival of love for Nature and application of natural science methods to sciences dealing with Man.

instruction: According to the passage only, how has the amount of knowledge required for education changed over time?
response: The passage notes an immense difference between knowledge required in olden times versus now. Five hundred years ago, knowing geometry made one a learned man; now every carpenter must know it. Knowing what lay beyond the Black Sea once indicated extraordinary learning, but now people travel to New Zealand, Hami, and Spitzbergen casually. The author's generation was considered educated with elementary geometry and algebra, but the coming generation will need to understand differential and integral analysis methods to be properly educated.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what reason does Kropotkin give for declining the invitation to stay at Haarlem?
response: Kropotkin explains that their position is as bad as it was the previous year, but they have the necessities of life, which he considers a great deal given conditions elsewhere in Europe. He does not explicitly decline but indicates they are managing where they are.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe Kropotkin's view on the Russian social revolution and its potential impact on Western European socialists.
response: Kropotkin states that the social revolution in Russia has taken a Centralist and authoritarian turn, but it still presents the possibility of a transition from capitalist to Socialist society. He believes this will encourage Western European Socialists in their efforts to reconstruct society on anti-capitalist equality, and that the Centralist faults of the Russian revolution will help workers in other countries avoid similar mistakes.

instruction: According to the passage only, what was Kropotkin's living situation and what work was he engaged in at the time of writing?
response: Kropotkin lived in a little town 60 kilometers north of Moscow with his wife and daughter. They had a small kitchen-garden that his wife worked, as he was no longer able to do physical work himself. He was engaged in writing a large work called 'Ethics on the Naturalist Basis.'

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author believe should be done with prisons?
response: The author believes prisons must be pulled down. He states that he does not see how prisons could be reformed and that the only proper way to combat crime is through prevention rather than punishment.

instruction: Using only the passage, what advice did the author give to Massachusetts prison officials who asked for his guidance?
response: The author advised them that if they cannot obtain the abolition of the prison system, they should never accept a child or youth in their prison, calling it manslaughter if they do. He also urged them to refuse to be jailers after learning what prisons are, and to continually advocate that prevention of crime is the only proper way to combat it.

instruction: According to the passage only, what methods does the author propose for preventing crime instead of using punishment?
response: The author proposes healthy municipal dwellings at cost price, education in the family and school for both parents and children, teaching every boy and girl a trade, communal and professional co-operation, societies for all sorts of pursuits, and developing idealism in youth that creates longing for higher interests that lift human nature.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what were Kropotkin's main reasons for declining to serve as treasurer of the proposed communist settlement?
response: Kropotkin declined because he considered himself the least appropriate person for the role, as he was never able to keep accounts of his own earnings and spendings. He also stated that he had no time for the position.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain Kropotkin's view on where communist communities should be established and why.
response: Kropotkin believed such experiments should be made near large cities rather than in distant countries. This would allow members to enjoy the benefits of civilization, make the struggle for life easier by taking advantage of existing infrastructure and neighbors' experience, and enable discontented members to easily return to individualist life. Members could also enjoy intellectual, scientific, and artistic life without abandoning the community.

instruction: According to the passage only, what type of agriculture did Kropotkin recommend for new communities and why?
response: Kropotkin recommended starting with intensive agriculture, specifically market gardening culture aided by culture under glass, rather than extensive agriculture. He argued that extensive agriculture involved hardships, accidents, drawbacks, and an amount of hard work often superior to the forces of the colonists.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author identify as the main cause of political and revolutionary defeats in the century?
response: The author argues that the main cause of defeats is that revolutionaries did not dare to advance and always looked backwards to the past for their ideals. Instead of dreaming of new revolutions, they sought to recreate past ones - in 1793 they dreamed of Rome or Sparta, in 1848 they wished to recommence 1792, and German revolutionists dreamed of reproducing 1848.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the author contrasts the approach of engineers and scientists with that of politicians and economists.
response: The author states that engineers, scholars, and artists boldly throw the past overboard and use new forces, materials, and observations to arrive at new conceptions. In contrast, politicians and economists seek their inspirations in the past. The author uses the example of the Forth bridge engineers who opened a new era of architecture by daring to innovate, and Darwin and Wallace who went to Nature for new observations rather than relying on old books.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author suggest is needed to construct a new society?
response: The author suggests that we shall not construct a new society by looking backwards. Instead, as Proudhon advised, we must study the tendencies of society today and forecast the society of tomorrow. This requires the same daring in politics and economics that has been shown in engineering, science, and the arts.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what two main causes does the author identify for the failure of communistic colonies?
response: The author identifies two main causes: First, colonies are usually not numerous enough—2000 souls will succeed better than 200 because variety of characters and aptitudes helps, and individuals' personalities more easily disappear in larger groups. Second, most communistic colonies place members into worse material conditions than their previous ones, requiring years of hard work fighting crushing difficulties while lacking the comforts of civilization and feeling less personal liberty.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author believes a communist colony would be better situated near London or Paris rather than in the wilderness.
response: The author argues that the privations one would endure to make a colony thrive in a London suburb would be much less than those required in places like Argentina. Near London, colonists could practice intensive gardening on available land, obtain advice from neighbors and real gardeners, and have access to factory work for necessary money. The author saw what could be obtained from poor clay soil at Harrow through intensive labor, convincing him that colonizing near cities is more practical than in unbroken wilderness countries.

instruction: According to the passage only, why do peasant colonies tend to succeed while colonies of workers from civilized countries often fail?
response: Peasant colonies succeed because conditions in their mother country are so bad that after 2-3 years of hard work, they feel better off than before. However, workers from civilized countries, if permitted to work, already have certain conditions of life that they typically cannot find in the colony. In colonies, they work hard but lack the trifles of civilization they enjoy, have no prospect of obtaining them, feel less personal liberty in small communities, and are deprived of higher stimuli like struggling in a large arena.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the purpose and organization of the trip across Canada that the author participated in.
response: After the British Association meeting ended, the Canadian Pacific Railway Association organized an instructive trip across the continent to Vancouver. The party of geologists and geographers stopped to visit main points of interest under the guidance of Dr. George Mercer Dawson (Director of the Geological Survey) and Professor Arthur Philemon Coleman. Local committees made arrangements to help participants see the country and its resources during stops along the route.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain the geographical comparison the author makes between crossing Canada and crossing the Old World.
response: The author was amazed at the resemblance between geographical features when crossing Canada from east to west and crossing the Old World from west to east at about the same latitude. He compares the woody regions of Eastern Canada to Northern Middle Russia, the hilly mining regions north of Lake Superior to the Urals, and the low prairies of Manitoba to the black-earth prairies of South Tobolsk at the foot of the Urals. He notes these same types of geographical regions appear in the same succession in both continents.

instruction: Using only the passage, what was the apparent attitude or approach of Canadians toward helping the author learn about the country?
response: The Canadians showed great cordiality and a desire to help the author judge the new lands for himself. Their apparent watchword was to give visitors all possible facilities to know everything by themselves while being careful not to prejudice them one way or another. The author notes he was offered facilities to see every settlement and town in the Northwest and Manitoba if time had permitted.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the symmetric structure that the author observes on both sides of the Pacific Ocean.
response: The author observes that the Pacific Ocean is encircled on both sides by two huge masses of plateaus that assume similar character in their outlines and the disposition of their outward slopes. The growth of these old continents proceeded chiefly on the outward slopes, producing repetition of the same geographical features in the same order. This symmetric structure resulted from some general telluric or cosmic force that acted at an angle to Earth's axis of rotation.

instruction: Based only on the passage, list at least five distinct geographical regions of Canada mentioned by the author.
response: The passage mentions these geographical regions of Canada: the maritime provinces of the Atlantic border; the woody regions of the St. Lawrence river with French population; the settled hills and plains of Ontario with British population; the Ontario peninsula between lakes Huron and Erie; the mining region of the Laurentian plateau in west Ontario; the boundless prairies with Indian population; the plateau and coast ranges with valleys and canyons; the peninsula of Labrador; the barren lands of the far north; and the Yukon district.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author feels a special connection to the prairies and steppes.
response: The author feels that the poetry of the Steppe is unknown to West Europeans and can only be found in Russian poetry and novels, and in the soul of those born in the Steppes. One must have lived there, rambled on horseback at sunset, inhaled the perfume of mowed grasses, spent nights in open air, and crossed boundless spaces to realize their beauty. The author notes that those born in such surroundings feel homesick elsewhere, and mountain valleys make them feel like a bird in a cage.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why wars are fought according to the author.
response: According to the passage, wars are no longer fought for personal reasons or national idiosyncrasies. Instead, they are fought for markets. Nations compete to find customers abroad for their manufactured goods, leading to a 'steeple-chase for markets' that drives international conflict.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the condition of Russian peasants and how Russia participates in the export economy.
response: Russian peasants are described as famine-struck, asking how to survive until the next harvest after eating their last flour mixed with dust and straw. Russia exports corn taken from peasants' mouths because when tax-gatherers come, peasants must sell so much harvest that they barely have black bread for nine months. They mix grass, straw, and bark with flour, and one-third of provinces face starvation each spring, yet exports rise.

instruction: According to the passage only, what is the 'leading principle' of production and what problem does it create for workers?
response: The leading principle of production is manufacturing merchandise for selling and realizing profits, not satisfying the needs of one's own country's people. Manufacturers seek customers anywhere on earth rather than addressing domestic needs. This creates a problem where laborers, reduced to living on as little as ten to twenty shillings weekly for a whole family, cannot afford the goods they produce. English produce goes to foreign customers rather than to the paupers of Whitechapel, Manchester, and Birmingham.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the chief result of the first twenty or thirty years of research after the Origin of Species appeared?
response: The chief result was proving two things: first, that no specific characters in plants or animals could not be altered by modifying their physical conditions of life; and second, that variations obtained experimentally under certain conditions (heat, cold, dryness, moisture, rich or poor nutrition) were exactly those characteristic of animals and plants living in corresponding natural environments like Arctic and Torrid zones, dry and wet climates, or fertile prairies and deserts.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what role Natural Selection was understood to play according to the research described.
response: Natural Selection was understood to play a subordinate part, described as a 'handmaid to Variation.' Its role was to weed out weaklings who lacked the necessary plasticity for undergoing changes in their tissues, organs, and habits. It would eliminate individuals slow in acquiring new adaptive features and keep a certain balance in the evolution of new characters, giving stability to new varieties.

instruction: According to the passage only, what example is given to illustrate how plants adapt to dry conditions?
response: The passage describes an experiment where a plant grown under a glass bell in very dry air had its leaves cease to develop succulent lobes, and the ribs of the leaves turned into spines or prickles. This demonstrated how spiny plants characteristic of dry regions could develop as a direct physiological result of dry conditions.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how Weismann's position on germ-plasm changed over time.
response: Initially, Weismann emphatically denied that his 'immortal' germ-plasm could be influenced by external agencies in the same direction as body changes. He maintained that mixture of germ-plasms in sexual reproduction (Amphimixis) was the only way hereditary influences could arise. However, he later abandoned the Amphimixis hypothesis and gradually came to accept 'Germinal Selection' and 'Parallel Induction' as hypotheses, acknowledging that germ-cells are modified by external causes to reproduce body changes in offspring.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was Darwin's criticism of the 'parallel induction' hypothesis?
response: Darwin pointed out that although simultaneous modification of body-cells and germ-cells in a definite direction occurs in certain special cases, this cannot be a general cause of hereditary transmission of variations. He noted that this hypothesis, like Amphimixis, does not account for inherited adaptive variations, which Darwin saw as necessary for the evolution of new species.

instruction: According to the passage only, how did most biologists view Weismann's 'Parallel Induction' hypothesis?
response: Most biologists received Weismann's 'Parallel Induction' hypothesis not as a new working hypothesis, but as a veiled concession to his opponents. The passage notes it was not a generalization born from studying changes in germ-cells under external agencies, but was advocated only as a hypothetical explanation for facts that contradicted Weismann's previous hypotheses.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what were the main reasons why more experiments proving hereditary transmission of acquired characters had not been conducted?
response: The passage lists several reasons: it is extremely difficult to breed plants and especially higher animals in conditions different enough to alter species characters; animals often fail to reproduce in unusual conditions and second generations frequently perished; experimenters only gradually learned that modifying causes must act at specific periods when reproductive cells are sensitive; experiments require many generations under modifying conditions to produce stable variations; such experiments were not in favor at most West-European universities until recently; and early research focused on proving species variability rather than inheritance of acquired characters.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did Lamarck indicate about the conditions necessary for variations to be inherited?
response: Lamarck indicated in his two laws of variation that changes must be slow and must take place for a succession of generations in order to be inherited and maintained later on for some time.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what Weismann initially believed about bud-variation and how his view changed.
response: In 1888, Weismann mistakenly believed there was no transmission of germ-plasm in vegetative reproduction and described bud-variation as an 'individual variation.' However, by 1904 he recognized his error and acknowledged, using almost the same words as Darwin, that a plant obtained through budding is as much a new individual as if it had been reproduced by seed.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what error did the author claim was made regarding germ-plasm transmission, and when was it corrected?
response: The author states that someone made the grave mistake of thinking there is no transmission of germ-plasm in vegetative reproduction, describing 'bud-variation' as an 'individual variation.' However, this error was recognized in 1904, when it was acknowledged that a plant obtained through budding is as much a new individual as if it had been reproduced by seed.

instruction: According to the passage only, why is vegetative reproduction considered more important than seed reproduction in the plant world?
response: The passage states that reproduction by buds (rootstocks, runners, and the like) is far more important than reproduction by seed in the vegetable world. It suggests that the immense majority of plants covering the northern part of the northern hemisphere have reproduced themselves since the Glacial period chiefly by buds, runners, and rootstocks, as Arctic and many Alpine plants still do.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the author says about the Steppes of South Russia and why the poetical description is criticized.
response: The passage mentions a poetical description claiming the Steppes of South Russia are covered with the same individuals of Grasses that withered under horses' hoofs during the Ugrian migration. The author criticizes this because a botanist knows that a bud on a rootstock contains the very same germ-plasm as the seed, so such pretty images should not be taken for scientific induction.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why Darwin believed 'sports' could not be the main factor in the evolution of new species.
response: Darwin pointed out that purely accidental sports could not explain the appearance of new species because they would not offer the accommodation to the environment that can only be supplied by definite and cumulative variation under the influence of a new environment, aided by Natural Selection.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was de Vries's early conclusion about the conditions needed to obtain inheritable variations?
response: In his earlier researches, de Vries concluded that rich nutrition in the wide sense (heavy manuring, keeping seedlings wide apart, etc.) was the first condition for obtaining such inheritable variations. He reached this conclusion in accordance with Professor J. MacLeod.

instruction: According to the passage only, why did botanists later question the value of Oenothera lamarckiana sports for the theory of descent?
response: Botanists recognized that Oenothera lamarckiana had a long history of cultivation in Europe since the mid-eighteenth century and could easily be a crossing of two other Evening Primrose species, which would explain its great variability rather than supporting a theory of descent through mutations.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what did de Vries recognize in his work 'Gruppenweise Artbildung' regarding mutations?
response: De Vries recognized that every mutation must have not only an inner cause but also an exterior cause, and that the high variability of the Oenotheras must be to some extent a consequence of the special conditions of the soil.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the experiments mentioned that showed mutations can be provoked by exterior influences.
response: The passage mentions Tower's experiments on the Colorado beetle using high temperatures, dryness of the air, and low atmospheric pressure; Blaringhem's experiments provoking inherited variations through mutilations of plants; and MacDougal's experiments acting directly on reproductive cells.

instruction: According to the passage only, what conclusion does Professor Klebs's work support regarding plant variations?
response: Professor Klebs found that plant characters which are most constant under ordinary conditions of culture can become most variable under properly chosen conditions, and that both continuous and discontinuous variations (mutations) can be obtained in the same individual depending on external conditions.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was Herbert Spencer's view on the two chief factors of evolution?
response: Herbert Spencer agreed with Darwin that both factors (Natural Selection and Direct Action of Environment) have been operative in evolution. However, he held that the inheritance of functionally caused alterations played a larger part than Darwin admitted, and that this factor has played the chief part in producing the highest types as evolution advanced.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how Weismann's views on evolution changed over time.
response: Weismann initially proclaimed the 'All-Sufficiency of Natural Selection' for giving origin to new species and rejected the necessity of inheritable adaptive changes produced by the environment. However, he gradually came to new hypotheses which actually recognised the part played in the evolution of new species by inherited variation.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did Standfuss conclude from his twenty-eight years of experiments?
response: Standfuss concluded that the mutual interaction between the agencies of the outer world and organisms gives origin to fluctuating new forms. These forms are inherited more or less, then sifted by Selection, and kept by it within definite lines of development. He also noted that the grip of older established traits cannot easily be overpowered by new variations.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain what Professor Ludwig Plate concluded about the relationship between Darwinism and Lamarckism.
response: Professor Plate concluded that Darwinism and Lamarckism taken together give a satisfactory explanation of the growing up of species, including the origin of adaptation, while neither theory taken separately provides this explanation. He argued that Natural Selection cannot refuse the collaboration of Lamarckian factors, as there are different ways in nature for increasing minimal differences to make them worthy of selection.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what the author says about Lamarck's relationship to the concept of Natural Selection.
response: The passage states that the idea of Natural Selection apparently did not occur to Lamarck, although several passages in his works suggest that he had noticed the struggle for existence.

instruction: According to the passage only, what criticism does the author make about the popularizers of Darwin's teachings?
response: The author criticizes the vulgarizers of Darwin's teachings for eliminating a deeply philosophical idea from the naturalistic conception of the universe. Speaking in the name of Science, they succeeded in persuading people that the last word of Science was a pitiless individual struggle for life, ignoring aspects of Nature that should have been foundations of human Ethics.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what did the vulgarisers of Darwin's teachings persuade men to believe was the last word of Science?
response: They persuaded men that the last word of Science was a pitiless individual struggle for life.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the prominence now given to the direct action of environment in species evolution help eliminate?
response: It helps eliminate the Malthusian idea about the necessity of a competition to the knife between all individuals of a given species for evolving new species.

instruction: Using only the passage, what did Bacon write about transmutation of plants in Sylva Sylvarum?
response: Bacon wrote that to have one plant change into another, the nourishment must overrule the inherited dispositions. He advised taking marsh-herbs and planting them on tops of hills and champaigns, and plants requiring much moisture upon sandy and very dry grounds, calling this the first rule for transmutation of plants.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why the Third Estate was granted double representation in the States-General.
response: Public opinion had been so predisposed in favor of the Third Estate by the provincial Assemblies that Necker and the Court were obliged to give in, despite the Assembly of Notables rejecting the doubling of numbers. This meant the Third Estate would have as many deputies as the clergy and nobility combined out of a thousand total deputies.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what Quinet observed about the middle classes before the Revolution.
response: Quinet noted the absence of serious protests and the servility of the middle classes. He observed that 'Nobody makes himself known' and there was 'dumbness, silence' in the provinces and towns. He questioned what future revolutionary heroes like Danton and Robespierre were doing during this time, highlighting the general passivity before the central power summoned men to vote.

instruction: According to the passage only, what was the status of serfdom in France by 1788?
response: Serfdom had long been abolished in France, at least on private estates. After Louis XVI abolished it within royal domains in 1779, only about 80,000 persons were held by mortmain in the Jura, with at most 1,500,000 in all of France (perhaps less than a million). Those subject to mortmain were not serfs in the strict sense. However, peasants continued paying money and performing statute labor as dues for holding land.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why Mirabeau argued that the resolutions of August 4 could not be subjected to the King's sanction.
response: Mirabeau argued that the resolutions of August 4 were enacted by the constituent power and therefore could not be subjected to sanction. He stated they were not laws but rather principles and constitutional bases, so they should have been forwarded for promulgation only, not for sanction.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the King's response on September 18th regarding the resolutions of August 4.
response: The King approved the general spirit of the articles of August 4 but gave only conditional assent to some of them. He concluded that he approved the greater number of these articles and would sanction them when they were worded as laws. This dilatory reply produced great discontent in the Assembly.

instruction: According to the passage only, what were the two alternatives the Constituent Assembly faced regarding feudal rights, and which did they choose?
response: The Assembly had two choices: either elaborate a scheme of laws on feudal rights (which would take months or years and divide the Assembly due to diverse opinions), or confine itself to proposing only principles to serve as bases for future laws. The Assembly chose the second alternative, quickly compiling resolutions that the King was eventually obliged to publish.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what England's primary concerns were regarding Germany's colonial and naval expansion.
response: England was jealous of keeping its supremacy on the seas and holding its colonies for exploitation by its own monopolists. It was frightened by the success of German Empire's colonial policy and the rapid development of its navy. England redoubled efforts to have a fleet capable of crushing the German fleet and looked for allies to weaken Germany's military power on land.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how the passage characterizes the actions of European powers in Africa and Asia.
response: The passage characterizes European actions as "brigandage" - Russian brigandage in Persia, Italian brigandage against desert Arabs around Tripoli, and French brigandage in Morocco. It describes a "consortium of brigands" serving monopolists who govern Europe, allowing various nations to seize territories. The Italians are said to massacre harmless Arabs, the French massacre Moors, and Russian hired assassins hang Persian patriots.

instruction: According to the passage only, what were the strategic locations that German colonial interests sought to control?
response: German colonial tycoons wished to conquer ports for export and especially military ports in the Mediterranean Adriatic, the Adriatic of the Indian Ocean (the Persian Gulf), on the African coast in Beira, and later in the Pacific Ocean.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how Kropotkin describes the evolution of someone who joins the Anarchist movement.
response: According to Kropotkin, when someone joins the Anarchists after being in a socialist or radical group, they initially view Anarchism as simply a more direct mode of action toward Social Revolution. Gradually, they become impassioned by the Anarchistic ideal and discover it is not Utopian but the result of an innate tendency in human society that has preserved the masses from complete enslavement by a power-hungry minority. Later still, they recognize that Anarchism forms an integral part of new ideas emerging about natural facts and represents a new method of thinking that differs from current scientific thought.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what three aspects does Kropotkin say he will consider Anarchism under, and in what order will he address them?
response: Kropotkin states he will consider Anarchism under three aspects: as a mode of action, as a social theory, and as part of a general system of philosophy. However, he says he will address them in inverse order—first developing ideas connecting Anarchist principles with accepted conceptions of natural facts, then considering Anarchism as a social theory, and lastly as a mode of action.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the historical shift in cosmological thinking that Kropotkin uses as an analogy for current philosophical changes.
response: Kropotkin describes how during a certain period, humans believed Earth was the center of the universe with the sun, planets, and stars revolving around it, all created for man who was protected by a supposed creator. This thinking dominated during periods of religious subjection and theocracies. As people threw off religious yokes, they discovered the sun was the center of our planetary system and was merely a grain of sand among millions of other suns. Kropotkin uses this shift to illustrate that an analogous important change is now occurring throughout scientific and philosophical thought.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how the Newtonian philosophy conceived of the solar system and its order.
response: The Newtonian philosophy described the sun as the lord of the planetary system who chained the earth, planets, and comets to their orbits through powerful attraction. He kept them at stated distances and compelled them to revolve around him. The sun was considered the heart, soul, king, and governor of the system. Perfect and rigid order reigned thanks to his power, and any factors of disorder were passing in nature, with the sun's attraction restoring equilibrium.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how the new scientific conception differs from the older Newtonian view regarding what maintains the solar system.
response: The new conception shifts focus from the central sun to infinitely small molecules of matter that circulate throughout space. These minute particles, when taken together, completely modify the force of the giants at the center. The central mass itself is now seen as the result of the action of these small molecules. These little particles build up the planets, retain heat in the sun, and by their rapid revolutions maintain the life of the whole system. Even attraction itself becomes the result of movements of molecules.

instruction: According to the passage only, how does the author connect Anarchism to the broader changes occurring in scientific and philosophical thought?
response: The author presents Anarchism as an essential and fundamental part of a new philosophy arising in scientific and philosophical thought—specifically the part treating social relations. Just as science now focuses on minute particles rather than central forces, Anarchism forms one of the most important parts of this method of conceiving nature. The author describes Anarchistic thought as a branch of a general method of reasoning that promises to become the philosophical thought of the civilized world.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the contradiction the author identifies in the Collectivist system.
response: The author argues that Collectivists proclaim a revolutionary principle—the abolition of private property—but then immediately deny it by maintaining an organization of production and consumption that springs from private property. They declare common ownership of land, factories, and machinery, yet then require workers to minutely calculate their individual contributions, count minutes of work, and weigh their labor against their neighbors'. The author contends a society cannot organize itself on two opposing principles that contradict each other at every step.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what is the author's criticism of unequal remuneration between qualified and simple labor in Socialist society?
response: The author criticizes that establishing distinctions between qualified/professional labor and simple labor maintains all the inequalities of existing society. It creates a demarcation between workers and those who claim to rule them, dividing society into two classes: an aristocracy of knowledge above and a laboring democracy below. The author argues this takes the distinctive features of middle-class society and sanctions them by social revolution, erecting into a principle what is already condemned as an abuse.

instruction: According to the passage only, what justification do economists and Marx provide for wage differences, and how does the author respond?
response: The passage states that middle-class economists and Marx argued there is good reason for a scale of wages because the 'labor force' of an engineer costs society more to produce than that of a navvy. Marx maintained this distinction was of logical necessity based on Ricardo's theory of value—that products exchange in proportion to the quantity of work socially necessary to produce them. The author responds skeptically, saying 'we know also how much of all this to believe,' suggesting the actual wage differences are not truly justified by these theoretical explanations.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author argue is necessary to achieve the utopia described, and what historical examples does he cite as precedents?
response: The author argues that a revolution is necessary to achieve the utopia. He cites the Anabaptist and Lutheran revolutions of the sixteenth century, the Cromwellian revolution of 1648, and the beginnings of the French Revolution as necessary preludes to later tolerance.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the author's criticism of Nietzsche's understanding of workers' issues.
response: The author criticizes Nietzsche for not understanding the economic workers' revolt because he had serfs to keep him alive and profited from their work. Despite being great in a certain revolt, Nietzsche remained a slave to bourgeois prejudice, which the author calls a terrible irony.

instruction: According to the passage only, why does the author consider the comparison between the unionist anarchist movement and the social democratic movement to be unfair?
response: The author finds the comparison unfair because while both movements may represent a limitation of the ideal in practice, they differ fundamentally in theory and practice. The social democratic movement is traditional and opposite of revolutionary, seeking to stop the course of events, while the anarchist syndicalist movement seeks to accelerate them.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how modern warfare battles differ from historical battles like Gravelotte, Potomac, and Borodino.
response: Modern warfare battles are fought on fronts of 35-40 miles rather than 5-10 miles, last 7-10 days instead of 3 days, and result in losses of 100,000-150,000 men on each side. The historical battles mentioned had 90,000-110,000 total killed and wounded on both sides and are described as child's play in comparison to modern warfare as seen in Manchuria.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the hand-to-hand combat that occurred at Port Arthur.
response: After attacking columns gained ground yard by yard and reached enemy trenches, soldiers engaged in brutal hand-to-hand combat. They hurled hand-grenades and pieces of pyroxyline at each other, with Japanese soldiers using pyroxyline tied with string as slings. Russian and Japanese soldiers rolled in trenches like wild beasts, striking with rifle butts and knives, and even tearing each other's flesh with their teeth.

instruction: According to the passage only, how do wars affect everyday life and the economy even during peacetime?
response: Wars destroy useful labor of millions of men during decades by wasting bread, meat, vegetables, food, beasts of burden, leather, coal, metal, and clothing. Even in peacetime, preparing war material causes industrial shocks and crises. The prices of bread, coal, railway tickets, and other articles depend on rumors about likelihood of war, which speculators propagate to raise prices. The passage states that great industrial crises were due to anticipation of wars.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what factors does the author say contributed to the revival of Geography as a science?
response: The author attributes the revival of Geography to the great revival of Natural Science over the preceding thirty years, the new direction given to scientific literature by prominent men who made complex research accessible to general readers, recent Arctic voyages and deep-sea explorations, and sudden progress in Biology, Climatology, Anthropology, and Comparative Ethnography.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author believes geography could be an effective teaching tool for children.
response: The author argues geography is effective because children search for stories about man and his struggles against obstacles. Tales of hunting, fishing, sea travels, struggles against dangers, customs, manners, traditions and migrations appeal to children's imagination. The author believes these elements make geography ideal for awakening children's desire to study nature and understand scientific reasoning.

instruction: According to the passage only, what contradiction does the author identify regarding geography in schools?
response: The author identifies that while nothing interests children more than travels, what is taught as Geography in most schools has become one of the driest and least attractive subjects. Despite geography being described as the most attractive and suggestive science for people of all ages, schools have managed to make it arid and unmeaning.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what does the author argue is the primary task of geography in early childhood education?
response: The author argues that geography's task in early childhood is to interest the child in the great phenomena of nature through the intermediary of man, awakening the desire of knowing and explaining them. By telling tales of far countries, their plants, animals, scenery and phenomena connected with human experience, geography can inspire children to want to penetrate the secrets of natural forces.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what the author believes geography should teach children about different nationalities and national conflicts.
response: Geography should teach children that all people are brethren regardless of nationality. It must show that each nationality contributes precious building stones to humanity's general development, that only small parts of each nation benefit from maintaining national hatreds, and that wars have been caused by short-sighted egotism. It should demonstrate that political frontiers are relics of a barbarous past and that the development of nationalities follows natural laws imposed by physical and ethnical characters of their regions.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author say ethnography has demonstrated about so-called 'savages' and their societies?
response: Ethnography has demonstrated that 'savages' have developed highly humane sociable feelings in their societies - the same feelings Europeans profess but seldom practice. Their 'barbarous customs' are either results of rough necessity or are forms of life that Europeans still live through in modified forms. Additionally, the superstitions found among savages are equally alive among Europeans, with only the names changed.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what assumptions does the author make about the young person he is addressing?
response: The author assumes the reader is about eighteen or twenty, finishing an apprenticeship or studies, has a mind free from superstitions, does not fear the Devil or listen to priests, is not a vain person dominated by appetite for pleasures, and has their heart in the right place with dreams of using their intelligence and knowledge to help liberate those in poverty and ignorance.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the contrast the author draws between the sick woman in the slum and the wealthy woman.
response: The woman in the slum is dying because all her life she has never eaten or rested enough, while the wealthy woman is wilting because all her life she has never known what work is. One suffers from deprivation and exhausting labor, while the other suffers from a frivolous lifestyle of sleepless nights spent on balls, visits, and quarrels.

instruction: According to the passage only, what scene does the author describe a young doctor encountering when visiting a sick person in a worker's home?
response: The doctor is led through narrow alleys to climb several flights of stairs covered in slippery filth, in foetid air lit by a lantern. In a dark, cold room, the invalid lies on a straw pallet covered in dirty rags. Pale, anaemic children shiver in tatters. The husband has been unemployed for three months after working twelve or thirteen hours daily, and the wife has been bedridden for two months, leaving the family in destitution.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain what the author argues is the true cause of nineteenth century wars.
response: The author argues that the true cause of nineteenth century wars is opening new markets and imposing one's own merchandise on others. Wars are fought to guarantee industrialists their profits, ensure financial barons their domination at the stock exchange, and provide shareholders of mines and railways with their incomes.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe how the nature of warfare changed from the old days to the present according to the author.
response: In the old days, wars were fought over kings' rivalries and insults between monarchs, with only a few thousand men enrolled. Now, whole peoples throw themselves upon each other, fighting not for kings' pleasure but for economic interests - the integrity of revenues and growing wealth of powerful financiers and industrialists like Rothschild, Schneider, and Anzin.

instruction: According to the passage only, what does the author say 'political preponderance' actually means when translated into material facts?
response: The author states that political preponderance, when translated into material facts, is quite simply a matter of economic preponderance in international markets. It means the right to impose goods and customs tariffs on neighbors, exploit industrially backward peoples, build railways to control frontiers, and appropriate ports or provinces for commercial advantage.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why the author believes forming a new political party is not the solution to highlighting the economic question for workers.
response: The author argues that if workers are not sufficiently aware of the importance of the economic question, forming a political party that relegates this question to the background will not highlight its importance. Instead of preserving and perpetuating this misconception, anarchists should work against it directly rather than through political party formation.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what the author identifies as the advantages of strikes over other proposed tactics like workers' representatives or political parties.
response: The author states that strikes and resistance have a great advantage over tactics like workers' representatives or constituting a workers' political party because those alternatives do not derail the movement but instead keep it perpetually in thrall to its principal enemy, the capitalist. Strikes provide a means to organize not only socialist converts but especially those who are not yet converted.

instruction: According to the passage only, why does the author believe strikes often fail and what solution is proposed?
response: The author states that strikes break out all over the place but fail all too often because they are isolated and abandoned to their own fate. The proposed solution is for striking workers to organize themselves, communicate among themselves, and build resistance associations for each trade in each town along with resistance funds.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how Darwin's work influenced fields beyond biology.
response: Darwin's work furnished a new key to understanding physical, vital, and social phenomena. The idea of continuous development (evolution) and adaptation to changing environment found wider application than just the origin of species. It was applied to the study of all nature, as well as to men and their social institutions, disclosing unknown horizons and explaining previously inexplicable facts.

instruction: Based on the passage, what earlier scholars contributed to the history of institutions before Darwin's influence?
response: The passage mentions enormous work done in the thirties by the school of Augustin Thierry in France, by Maurer and the 'Germanists' in Germany, and later in Russia by Kostomárov, Belyáev and others. The principle of evolution had been applied to manners, institutions, and languages since the time of the encyclopædists.

instruction: According to the passage, what were the limitations of metaphysical generalizations compared to scientific induction?
response: Metaphysical generalizations were characterized by hopeless indefiniteness. They were deduced through fallacious syllogisms with meager premises concealed by misty words and obscure exposition. Semi-conscious inductions were based on limited observations and presented as hard laws when they were merely hypotheses requiring verification. Their abstract forms allowed for varied and often opposite practical conclusions.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the character and interests of the narrator's mother.
response: The mother was described as a remarkable woman for her times. She was tall, slim, with dark chestnut hair, dark brown eyes, and a tiny mouth. She had the nature of an artist - she kept diaries about German scenery and her emotions, copied prohibited Russian verses and poetry by Lamartine and Byron, transcribed French dramas and music, and created water-colour paintings. She was always lively, often careless, and fond of dancing. She would watch peasant women's ring-dances and sometimes join them. All who knew her loved her, and servants worshipped her memory.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what happened to the narrator's grandfather Nikolái Semyónovich Sulíma and why he remained poor.
response: The grandfather served as a cuirassier regiment commander during Napoleon I's invasion, where he cut his way into a French infantry square and survived being left for dead with a deep head wound. However, he could not become a valet to Arakchéeff, Alexander I's omnipotent favourite, so he was sent into honorary exile as governor-general of West Siberia and later East Siberia. Though such positions were considered more lucrative than gold-mines, he returned from Siberia as poor as he went because he was driven to despair by wholesale stealing in those provinces which he had no means to repress.

instruction: According to the passage only, how did the servants and peasants treat the narrator and his brother after their mother's death?
response: The servants and peasants lavished care upon the narrator and his brother because they were their mother's children and bore likeness to her. The Russian nurse Uliána would sign them with the cross and speak of their mother watching from the skies. Servants would caress them in dark passages, and peasant women meeting them in fields would ask if they would be as good as their mother, who had taken compassion on the serfs. The passage states they found an atmosphere of love among the serf servants in their house.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what happened at the battle of Máloyaroslávetz according to M. Poulain's account.
response: According to M. Poulain, the Russians tried to check Napoleon's advance at Máloyaroslávetz. He explained that when the Cossacks attempted a flanking movement, Davout or another marshal routed and pursued them. The left wing of Napoleon crushed the Russian infantry, and Napoleon himself charged Kutúzoff's centre at the head of the Old Guard, covering himself and his Guard with glory. M. Poulain presented it as the Grande Armée crushing the Russians and making its way through their lines.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain why M. Poulain was less eloquent when discussing Tarútino compared to Máloyaroslávetz.
response: M. Poulain was less eloquent about Tarútino because it was the place where Napoleon was compelled to abandon his plan to retreat by a southern route after a bloody battle. Napoleon was forced to take the Smolénsk route instead, which his army had already laid waste during its march on Moscow. In M. Poulain's narrative, Napoleon did not lose the battle but was deceived by his marshals.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the narrator's experience walking through the pine forest beyond Kalúga.
response: The narrator found it delightful to walk alone through the beautiful pine forest. The sand was as deep as in an African desert, and immense centuries-old red pines rose on every side with no sound except the voices of the lofty trees. In a small ravine, a fresh crystal spring murmured with a birch bark ladle left by a passer-by. A squirrel ran noiselessly up a tree, and the underwood was full of mysteries. The narrator's first love of Nature and first dim perception of its incessant life were born in that forest.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe what happened to Sásha the Doctor after he returned from his medical training.
response: After returning from his training, Sásha the Doctor set up a well-equipped dispensary at Nikólskoye. He became popular in the region by gathering and preparing medical herbs and treating sick peasants from neighboring villages. However, one winter after the narrator's father visited briefly and left, Sásha shot himself. Though it was reported as an accident, there was a love story behind it—he was in love with a girl he could not marry because she belonged to another landowner.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain how Gherásim Kruglóff's fate changed after being sent away as a soldier.
response: After being sent away as a soldier in chains, Gherásim's situation improved when Nicholas I died and military service became more tolerable. His great ability was soon noticed, and within a few years he became one of the chief clerks and the real working force in a department of the Ministry of War. He later helped the narrator's father obtain a promotion by making a favorable report, despite how he had been treated.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the irony in how the narrator's stepmother eventually needed Gherásim Kruglóff's help.
response: The stepmother had previously offended Gherásim at every opportunity and was responsible for having him arrested and sent away as a soldier after he refused to shut a gate for her. Years later, when she needed help getting the narrator's father promoted to general, she discovered that the only person who could help was Gherásim Kruglóff, now a powerful clerk. Despite their history, he agreed to help, saying he had nothing against the old prince, and he kept his word.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the teaching method Herr Becker used for students who knew no German (the 'Kamchátka' section).
response: Becker required students in the Kamchátka section to copy four lines he chose from a book at each lesson. Once they finished copying, they could do what they liked as long as they didn't hinder the rest of the class. The number of lines increased in higher forms. By choosing the lines carefully and giving attention to these students, Becker helped them learn something of German and its literature by the end of five years.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the heir-apparent was brought to the corps of pages for algebra lessons.
response: The Empress Marie Alexándrovna, who was an educated woman, thought that contact with studious boys might stimulate her son to learning. He attended Captain Sukhónin's algebra lessons and had to answer questions like the other students.

instruction: According to the passage only, how did the narrator learn German and what was his experience reading Goethe's 'Faust'?
response: The narrator joined the German section, translated and studied a difficult poetical description of a thunderstorm, learned conjugations, adverbs, and prepositions by heart, and began reading. He also subscribed to a cheap illustrated weekly on Becker's advice. When he read Goethe's 'Faust' in the original German, he experienced unfathomable joy, drinking in the sense and music of every line, learning full pages by heart, and finding verses like Faust's monologue in the forest put him in ecstasy.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the narrator's experience of reading poetry in a language not fully understood.
response: The narrator describes reading poetry in a partially understood language as creating a higher aesthetic delight. The whole is veiled with a slight haze that suits poetry well. Words retain only their subtle, elevated sense rather than trivial colloquial meanings that might interfere with poetical images, while the music of the poetry is more strongly impressed upon the ear.

instruction: Based only on the passage, explain what made Professor Klasóvsky's teaching style unique and how students responded to it.
response: Instead of giving dull grammar lessons, Klasóvsky compared old Russian folklore with lines from Homer or the Sanskrit Mahabharata, introduced verses from Schiller, made sarcastic remarks about modern society prejudices, and offered wide poetical or philosophical generalizations. Students clustered around him like a swarm of bees, hung on his lips breathlessly, and sat motionless. Even restless and obtuse students were captivated, as if a vision of an unsuspected world was opening before them.

instruction: According to the passage only, what role does the author believe the teacher of literature should play in education?
response: The teacher of literature should bind together separate historical and humanitarian sciences, unify them by a broad philosophical and humane conception, and awaken higher ideas and inspirations in young people. While each teacher has their own subject with no link between them, the literature teacher can introduce a generalized conception of the development of the human mind that lies beyond the scope of subjects taught separately. The author believes every school ought to have such a teacher.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe how the teacher Ebert responded when a student threw an ink-soaked sponge at him.
response: Instead of reporting the incident to the inspector, Ebert wiped his face with his handkerchief and reminded the class of their agreement: 'One frolic—no more to-day!' He added quietly that his shirt was spoiled, then continued correcting a student's book. This response made the students feel ashamed and shifted their feelings in his favor.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the students disliked the drawing teacher Ganz and considered him dishonest.
response: The students disliked Ganz because he constantly reported those who misbehaved in class, which they felt he had no right to do as 'only a teacher of drawing.' They also considered him dishonest because he spent class time improving drawings for students who paid him for private lessons or who paid to have good drawings to show at examinations, rather than teaching the whole class fairly.

instruction: According to the passage only, what did the author believe should be part of education regarding nature and science?
response: The author believed that the poetry of nature, the methods of all the exact sciences, and an inspired conception of the life of nature must make part of education. The author suggested that a geography teacher might assume this function, but noted that a different set of geography teachers and university professors would be needed, as what was currently taught as geography was not truly geography.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the narrator's reading habits during Saturday night visits to his sister Hélène's house.
response: The narrator spent most of Saturday nights reading from his brother-in-law's library, which contained French philosophers and historians. He read works of the encyclopædists, Voltaire's 'Philosophical Dictionary', and writings of the Stoics, especially Marcus Aurelius. These books were prohibited in Russia and could not be taken to school.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain Alexander's intellectual interests and how they evolved over time.
response: Alexander initially embraced the Lutheran faith and studied the Augsburg declaration. He later moved to Kantian agnosticism, discussing concepts like 'relativity of perceptions' and 'perceptions in time and space.' He also became interested in transformism after reading lectures by Professor Roulier, studying heredity and the variability of species. He temporarily took up political economy, becoming passionate about tariffs and customs duties.

instruction: According to the passage only, what was the narrator's reaction to political economy compared to his brother's interest in it?
response: The narrator had little interest in political economy, reading only a few chapters of Jean Baptiste Say's work and finding tariffs and banking operations uninteresting. In contrast, Alexander took up these matters passionately, even writing letters to their stepmother about customs duties and becoming frustrated when others showed indifference to tariff questions.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the problem the narrator encountered when one of the barges became stuck and how it was eventually resolved.
response: One of the barges became stuck on a rock at the foot of a high inaccessible cliff. As the river level dropped, the barge couldn't be moved, and when they tried to push it off, the bottom broke and water entered, sweeping away cargo. The narrator didn't know how to fix it, but a Cossack officer friend arrived with an empty barge. They filled the hole with a sack of flour (which forms a paste crust to prevent water penetration), pumped out the water, and transferred the cargo to the new barge.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what was the narrator's role and who was his superior in the flotilla operation?
response: The narrator was nominated as assistant to the chief of the flotilla. His superior was Major Maróvsky, who was the chief of all the barges (twenty to thirty in total) that were placed under the orders of Cossack and civil-service officers.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the challenges the narrator faced with his crew at the start of the journey.
response: The narrator had to hire men who had no experience in river navigation, and neither did he. On the morning of departure, the crew had to be collected from public-houses, with most of them so drunk at that early hour that they had to be bathed in the river to bring them back to their senses. The narrator then had to teach them everything that needed to be done on the barges.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the author and his brother decided to leave military service and return to Russia.
response: The passage indicates they decided to leave military service because Alexander would have refused to march if ordered to act against something he opposed (another officer was assigned to command the mobilized squadron under some pretext). The author states he would have done the same if he had been at Irkutsk. They then decided to leave military service and return to Russia.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe what the author discovered about the true structure of Asian mountains after years of research.
response: The author discovered that the main structural lines of Asia run from southwest to northeast, not north-south or west-east as previously believed. He found that Asian mountains are not independent ridges like the Alps, but are subordinated to an immense plateau - an old continent that once pointed toward Behring Strait. High border ridges formed along its fringes, and terraces of later sediments emerged from the sea over time, adding width to this primitive backbone of Asia.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain the author's methodology for investigating the geography of Northern Asia.
response: The author used a purely inductive approach. He collected all barometrical observations from previous travelers and calculated hundreds of altitudes from them. He marked geological and physical observations (facts, not hypotheses) from different travelers on a large-scale map. He then tried to determine what structural lines would best match the observed realities. This preparatory work took over two years, followed by months of intense thought until the pattern became clear.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe Makláy's ethical principles when dealing with native peoples.
response: Makláy's ethics centered on always being straightforward with natives and never deceiving them, not even in the most trifling matters or for scientific purposes. He was most scrupulous about this, even refusing to photograph a sleeping native servant despite the scientific value, because he had promised never to photograph him.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what happened to Fédchenko and how was his work preserved?
response: Fédchenko was killed in a snowstorm while climbing a mountain in Switzerland. He had undertaken the ascent without proper guides. After his death, his wife Olga Fédchenko completed the publication of his 'Travels,' and the passage mentions she likely has a son who continues the work of both parents.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain how Prjeválsky's approach to expeditions changed over time and what concerns this raised.
response: Prjeválsky made his first journey with only three comrades and kept excellent terms with natives. However, as his subsequent expeditions took a more military character, he began relying on the force of his armed escort rather than peaceful intercourse with natives. Well-informed sources suggested that if he hadn't died at the start of his Tibet expedition, he very probably would not have returned alive.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the narrator declined the position of secretary to the Geographical Society.
response: While working in Finland, the narrator had time to reflect and other thoughts and longings had pervaded his mind. When he received the telegram offering the secretary position, he had seriously reconsidered his direction in life, leading him to decline despite his earlier hopes of obtaining such a position.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe what the narrator observed about the Finnish peasants during his journey.
response: The narrator saw what an immense amount of labour the Finnish peasant spends in clearing the land and in breaking up the hard boulder clay.

instruction: According to the passage only, what was the narrator's original intention for writing about Russian geography?
response: The narrator intended to write an exhaustive physical geography of Russia, giving a thorough geographical description based on the main lines of surface structure, and to sketch different forms of economic life that ought to prevail in different physical regions, treating each region scientifically as Karl Ritter treated parts of Asia.

instruction: Using only the passage, describe the process the narrator went through upon arriving at the fortress as a prisoner.
response: Upon arriving at the fortress, the narrator was taken through multiple gates and narrow passages. In a small, dark and damp room, he was required to remove all his clothes and put on prison dress consisting of a green flannel dressing-gown, immense thick woollen stockings, and large boat-shaped yellow slippers. He was initially forced to remove even his silk undergarment, but after protesting for about an hour, it was restored to him by order of General Korsákoff. He was then taken through a dark passage with armed sentries and put into a cell.

instruction: Based only on the passage, what historical events and figures does the narrator associate with the fortress of St. Peter and St. Paul?
response: The narrator associates the fortress with terrible historical events spanning two centuries. Peter I tortured and killed his son Alexis there with his own hand. Princess Tarakánova was kept in a cell that filled with water during an inundation, with rats climbing on her. The terrible Minich tortured his enemies there, and Catherine II buried alive those who objected to her having murdered her husband. The narrator describes the fortress's annals as being of murder and torture.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain what prediction the narrator made about his imprisonment and why.
response: When the Circassian officer suggested his affair might be brought to court in a fortnight, the narrator predicted he would remain in the fortress for a couple of years. He explained that although his own affair was simple, the authorities would try to arrest all the socialists in Russia before bringing him to court, and since there were very many socialists, they would not be done in two years. The narrator later noted that this remark proved to be prophetic.

instruction: Based only on the passage, describe the exercise routine the narrator devised while imprisoned.
response: The narrator determined to walk seven versts (about five miles) daily, divided into two versts in the morning, two before dinner, two after dinner, and one before sleep. He would walk ten steps from corner to corner, repeating this 150 times to make one verst, using cigarettes on a table to count 300 passes. He also practiced gymnastics twice daily with a heavy stool, lifting it by one leg at arm's length, turning it like a wheel, and throwing it between hands over his head, behind his back, and across his legs.

instruction: Using only the passage, explain why the narrator was denied pen and ink and how he eventually obtained them.
response: Pen and ink were never allowed in the fortress unless special permission was obtained from the Emperor himself. The narrator eventually obtained pen and ink through his brother Alexander, who secured them for him.
